R. Khan'''), [[Civil decorations of Pakistan|HQA]], [[Nishan-e-Pakistan|HPk]], [[Hilal-e-Jurat|HJ]], was a [[Three-star rank|three-star]] rank [[admiral]], [[Pakistani politician|politician]], and the [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan Navy)|Commander in Chief]] of [[Pakistan Navy]], serving under [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)|Ayub Khan]] from 1959 until 1966. Prior to that, he also simultaneously served in the [[Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)|Ayub Khan]]'s [[Stratocracy|administration]] as an [[Interior Minister of Pakistan|Interior Minister]] and [[Defence Minister of Pakistan|Defence Minister]] until resigning when General [[Yahya Khan]], an [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan Army)|Army Commander-in-Chief]], enforced a [[Martial law in Pakistan|martial law]] in 1969. Gaining [[Officer (armed forces)|commission]] in [[Royal Indian Navy (1612–1950)|Royal Indian Navy]] in 1938, he served in [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1947|first war]] with India in 1947 in non-combat operations but earned notability and prestige when he commanded the [[Pakistan Navy]] against [[Indian Navy]] during the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|war]] with India in 1965. In addition, he is noted for being the longest serving [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|commander-in-chief]] of [[Pakistani Navy|navy]] as well as responsible for launching and introducing the [[List of active Pakistan Navy ships|submarine program]] in the navy.{{Cite web| last = Pillar of Pakistan| first = | authorlink = | author2 = | title = Chiefs of Naval Staff| work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.pillarsofpakistan.com/navy_staff.html| doi = | accessdate = | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20101101092607/http://www.pillarsofpakistan.com/navy_staff.html| archive-date = 1 November 2010| dead-url = yes| df = dmy-all}} ==Biography== Afzal Akram Rahman Khan was born in [[British Indian Empire]] in 1921, and it is known very little on his early life primarily based on literature published in combined [[Military history of South Asia|military history]] of [[Military history of Pakistan|Pakistan]] and [[Military history of India|India]]. As many of his contemporaries in the [[Indian military|British Indian military]], he was educated at the [[Rashtriya Indian Military College]] at [[Dehradun]], and gained [[Commissioned officer|commission]] as a [[Midshipman]] in the [[Royal Indian Navy (1612–1950)|Royal Indian Navy]] in 1938. He was also trained as [[naval artillery]] specialist from [[Britannia Royal Naval College]] in [[United Kingdom]] and participated in [[World War II]] on behalf of [[Great Britain]].{{rp|190}}{{cite book|last1=Roy|first1=Mihir K.|title=War in the Indian Ocean|publisher=Lancer Publishers, Roy|isbn=9781897829110|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tqr8r7EB18wC&pg=PA190&dq=Afzal+Rahman+Khan+defence+minister&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwig6NSTjIjQAhVT42MKHVDUDVsQuwUIHzAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=1 November 2016|language=en}} After [[World War II]], he studied at the [[Command and Staff College]] in 1945 and graduated with a [[staff officer|staff course]] degree in 1946.{{cite web|last1=Army staff college|title=Gallery Alumni|url=http://armystaffcollege.gov.pk/Gallery_Alumni.php|website=armystaffcollege.gov.pk|publisher=Command and Staff College|accessdate=1 November 2016}} During this time, he was contemporary to [[Gopal Gurunath Bewoor]] ({{small|[[Indian Army]]}}), [[Iqbal Khan (general)|Iqbal Khan]] and [[Abdul Hamid Khan (general)|Abdul Hamid Khan]]– all became generals in [[Indian Army|Indian]] and [[Pakistan Army]]. He provided his gunnery services to [[HMS Duke of York (17)|''HMS Duke of York'']] at the time of the [[Partition of India|partition]] of [[British Indian Empire|British India]] and decided to [[Pakistani citizenship|opted]] for [[Pakistan]] in [[1947 in Pakistan|1947]].{{rp|190}} He did not actively participated in [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1947|first war]] with [[India]] in 1947, instead he commanded a destroyer from [[Karachi]] to [[Mumbai]] to oversee the evacuation of [[Muhajir people|Indian emigrants]] to Pakistan. He was among the first twenty naval officers who joined the [[Royal Pakistan Navy]] (RPN) as a [[Lieutenant (naval)|Lieutenant]] with a [[service number]] PN. 0006.{{cite web|last1=Kazi|first1=KGN|title=The first few executive officers transferred to the Pakistan Navy on Partition|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/pimu/5346639918/|website=Flickr|publisher=Dr. KGN Kazi archives of 1950s|accessdate=2 November 2016}} He was the third most senior Lieutenant in the navy in terms of seniority list provided by the [[Royal Indian Navy]] to the [[Ministry of Defense (Pakistan)|Ministry of Defense]] (MoD) in 1947. In 1949, he was promoted as [[Lieutenant-Commander]] and served as [[commanding officer]] of [[PNS Tariq (D129)|PNS Tariq]], the first [[destroyer]], when it was commissioned from the [[Royal Navy]] on 30 September 1949.{{cite web|last1=Virtuti Militari|title=The First Destroyer|url=http://pakdef.org/the-first-destroyer/|website=pakdef.org|publisher=« PakDef Military Consortium|accessdate=1 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060749/http://pakdef.org/the-first-destroyer/|archive-date=4 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In 1950, he was promoted as [[Commander]] and commanded the [[PNS Tippu Sultan (D49)|''Tippu Sultan'']] and sailed on a goodwill mission to [[Middle East]] and [[Eastern Europe]]; he visited [[Jeddah]], [[Malta]], [[Venice]], [[Athens]], [[Istanbul]], [[Izmir]] and [[Crete]]. In 1951, he participated in [[Task Force 90|Task Force 91]] that was held in [[Trincomalee]] [[Sri Lanka]] with the [[Royal Navy]]. At Trincomalee, they had a rendezvous with a large force (9 ships) of the Royal Navy, the Indian Navy and the Royal Ceylon Navy. It led to 14 days of strenuous exercises in harbour and at sea. The officers and men from these ships also took part in various Inter Services Tournaments. His career progressed well in the navy and helped establish the [[Naval Intelligence (Pakistan)|Naval Intelligence]] (NI) and helped establish the [[Karachi Naval Dockyard]]. In 1958–59, the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Naval NHQ]] staff had been in a brief conflict with the [[Ministry of Defence (Pakistan)|Ministry of Defence]] over the rearmament issues which eventually led the resignation of Vice-Admiral [[Haji Mohammad Siddiq Choudri|HMS Choudrie]].{{cite news|last1=Nadia Ghani|title=NON-FICTION: The narcissist|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/546401|accessdate=1 November 2016|work=DAWN.COM|publisher=Nadia Ghani, Dawn|date=11 July 2010}} Afzal Rahman Khan was never appointed to [[Four-star rank|four-star admiral]] rank but nonetheless was appointed as [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan Navy)|Commander in Chief]] of [[Pakistan Navy]] after his nomination papers were approved by then-[[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Iskander Mirza]] in 1959.{{rp|104}}{{cite book|last1=Rizvi|first1=H.|title=Military, State and Society in Pakistan|publisher=Springer, Rizvi|isbn=9780230599048|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZwGIDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA104&lpg=PA104&dq=Afzal+Rahman+Khan+admiral&source=bl&ots=_Ehgkh7dqq&sig=ibKpOiuLDZo1ytX8gPtjXbKdKrQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiap629mojQAhXBwVQKHT1sDQ84ChDoAQgeMAE#v=onepage&q=Afzal%20Rahman%20Khan%20admiral&f=false|accessdate=1 November 2016|language=en}} Prior to his appointment as [[commander in chief]] of navy, his command responsibilities included as his role as [[Pakistan Navy#commands|Commander Pakistan Fleet]] (COMPAK) and Commander Logistics (COMLOG) commands headquartered in [[Karachi]], [[Sindh]] with being promoted to the [[two-star rank|two-star]] rank of [[Rear-Admiral]]. After promoting as [[Vice-Admiral]], he oversaw the induction of submarines in the navy in 1960s; for this, he is viewed as the "father of submarines force" of Pakistan Navy.{{cite web|last1=Recorder|first1=Business|title=THEY LED THE WAR|url=http://www.brecorder.com/taxation/181:pakistan/1225143:underinvoicing-termed-a-major-issue/|website=Business Recorder|accessdate=1 November 2016}}{{Cite web|last= |first=[[Vice Admiral]] (retired) Ahmed Tasneem |author=Ahmed Tasneem |author2=A.H Amin |title=Recollections about 1965 war |work= |publisher= |date= |url=http://www.chowk.com/ilogs/65191/47736 |format= |doi= |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204234436/http://www.chowk.com/ilogs/65191/47736 |archivedate=4 December 2008 }} He earned public notability when he acted as a leader during the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|war]] with [[India]] in 1965 despite having prior no knowledge on [[Operation Gibraltar|covert operation]] in [[Indian-held Kashmir|Indian Kashmir]].{{rp|24}}{{cite book|last1=Anwar|first1=Muhammad|last2=Baig|first2=Ebad|title=Pakistan: Time for Change|publisher=AuthorHouse, Anwar|isbn=9781477250303|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mb6OOYcrIOYC&pg=PA25&dq=AR+Khan+1965+war&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwicq5i1nIjQAhUK1GMKHZaqCD8QuwUIIDAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=1 November 2016|language=en}} He oversaw the planning of and execution of the [[Operation Dwarka|naval operation]] to attack the [[Indian Navy]] which earned him the prestige in the country.{{rp|25}} After the war, he was publicly honored and was decorated with [[Hilal-i-Jurat]] by President Ayub Khan.{{cite book|last1=Cardozo|first1=Major General Ian|title=The Sinking of INS Khukri: Survivor's Stories|publisher=Roli Books Private Limited, Cardozo|isbn=9789351940999|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xvs_CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT28&dq=AR+Khan+minister+navy&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiYwKSin4jQAhVU_WMKHceFA88QuwUIOTAC#v=onepage&q=AR%20Khan%20minister%20navy&f=false|language=en}} He is noted for his multiple extension in the navy that made him noted as the longest serving chief of staff of navy. He was known to be closer to President [[Ayub Khan (general)|Ayub Khan]] who appointed him as the [[Defence Minister of Pakistan|Defence]] and [[Interior Minister of Pakistan|Interior Minister]] in 1966 while serving as an active-duty admiral.{{rp|104}} About the [[1969 uprising in East Pakistan|uprising and riots]] in [[East Pakistan|East-Pakistan]] in 1969, Vice-Admiral Rahman told the journalists that the "[[Pakistan|country]] was under the [[Ochlocracy|Mob rule]] and that [[Police Service of Pakistan|Police]] were not strong enough to tackle the situation."{{rp|130}}{{cite book|last1=Siddiqui|first1=Kalim|title=Conflict, Crisis and War in Pakistan|publisher=Springer, Siddiqui|isbn=9781349013395|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f86uCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA130&dq=AR+Khan+minister+resigned&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjhhMaVnojQAhVT3GMKHduzAXAQuwUIJDAB#v=onepage&q=AR%20Khan%20minister%20resigned&f=false|accessdate=1 November 2016|language=en}} He served in ministerial post until 1969 when President [[Ayub Khan (general)|Ayub Khan]] resigned and handed over the [[Pakistani presidency|presidency]] to his [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan Army)|Army Commander-in-Chief]] General [[Yahya Khan]] who [[Martial law in Pakistan|suspended]] the [[Constitution of Pakistan of 1962|Constitution]]. In protest to the [[Martial law in Pakistan|martial law]], Vice-Admiral A.R. Khan resigned from his portfolio on 25 March 1969.{{Cite web | last =Pillar of Pakistan | first = | authorlink = | author2 = | title= Defense and Interior Ministries:Vice-Admiral Afzal Rahman Khan | work = | publisher = | date = | url =http://rulers.org/pakgov.html | doi = | accessdate = }} Khan resigned from the ministries as a protest when General Yahya Khan, instituted another martial law on 25 March 1969.{{Cite web | last =Pillar of Pakistan | first = | authorlink = | author2 = | title=Chief ExecutivesVice-Admiral Afzal Rahman Khan | work = | publisher = | date = | url =http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Pakistan_states.html | doi = | accessdate = }} After his resignation, Khan retired from [[Politics of Pakistan|national politics]] and moved to [[Islamabad]] in 1969 where he lived a very quiet and private life. He did not comment on [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1971|war with India]] in 1971 as he diminished his role from the politics in 1970s. In 1987, the Pakistan Navy honored him after establishing a [[PNS Makran|naval base]] under his name.{{cite web|last1=Pak def|title=Their Name Liveth for Ever More|url=http://pakdef.org/their-name-liveth-for-ever-more/|website=pakdef.org|publisher=Pak def|accessdate=1 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180911081756/http://pakdef.org/their-name-liveth-for-ever-more/|archive-date=11 September 2018|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The [[PNS Makran|PNS Akram]] now serves as a forward operating base for the Navy and acts as a depot for all naval personnel stationed west of Ormara. He avoided the [[Pakistani media|media]] and lived on a [[Pension in Pakistan|military pensions]]; he died at an old age in Islamabad in 2005. His death went unnoticed in the media and was quietly buried in Islamabad with close family members attending his funeral. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.paknavy.gov.pk/ Official website of Pakistan Navy] {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[HMS Choudri]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|Commander-in-Chief, Pakistan Navy]]|years=1959–1966}} {{s-aft|after=[[Syed Mohammad Ahsan]]}} |- {{s-off}} {{succession box |title=[[Interior Minister of Pakistan]] |years=1966–1969 |before=[[Chaudhry Ali Akbar Khan]]| after=[[Abdul Hamid Khan (general)|Abdul Hamid Khan]]}} |- {{succession box |title=[[Defence Minister of Pakistan]] |years=1966–1969 |before=[[Ayub Khan (Field Marshal)|Ayub Khan]]| after=[[Yahya Khan]]}} {{end}} {{Military of Pakistan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Khan, Afzal Rahman}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:Anglo-Indian people]] [[Category:Rashtriya Indian Military College alumni]] [[Category:Royal Indian Navy officers]] [[Category:Indian people of World War II]] [[Category:People of the Indo-Pakistani War of 1947]] [[Category:Pakistan Navy admirals]] [[Category:Chiefs of Naval Staff, Pakistan]] [[Category:People of the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965]] [[Category:Interior Ministers of Pakistan]] [[Category:Defence Ministers of Pakistan]] [[Category:Recipients of Hilal-i-Jur'at]] [[Category:Admirals of the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965]]

{{blp-refimprove|date=November 2014}} '''Alpana Singh''' (born November 1976) is an [[Indian American|American]] [[Master Sommelier]], restaurateur and local [[television personality]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]].
==Early life== Singh is a second-generation [[Indian American]], born and raised in [[Monterey, California|Monterey]], [[California]]. Her parents are [[Indians in Fiji|Fiji Indians]] who migrated from [[Fiji]] to California.<ref name=mastersomm>[http://www.mastersommeliers.org/member=55 Profile at Master Sommeliers.org]</ref> The family owned and ran an ethnic grocery store.<ref name="About Me">{{cite web| url= http://www.alpanasingh.com/aboutme/ |title= About Me| website= alpanasingh.com| deadurl= yes| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20141229045044/http://www.alpanasingh.com/aboutme/| archivedate= December 29, 2014| access-date= July 21, 2018}}</ref> Her father was a chef for 30 years.<ref name="venture audio">[http://www.wbez.org/blogs/bez/2012-05/alpana-singh-steps-out-cellar-lead-new-restaurant-98898 Alpana Singh discusses restaurant venture (audio)], ''Afternoon Shift'', [[WBEZ]], 7 May 2012.</ref>
==Career== Singh's first job in the restaurant business outside the family business was as a waitress at [[Bakers Square]].<ref name="venture audio" /> After an aborted attempt to join the [[US Air Force]] (due to a failed medical exam),{{cn|date= July 2018}} she applied for a job at a fine dining restaurant but needed better background on wines. She self-educated and re-applied for the job, impressing the interviewer, who hired her and encouraged her to continue her studies.<ref name="venture audio" /> She became a sales clerk at Nielsen Bros. Market in [[Carmel, California]] which further exposed her to the wine business.<ref name="About Me" />
Singh passed the [[Court of Master Sommeliers]]' advanced certification test at age 21.<ref name=cbiz >{{cite news| last= White |first= Sara D.| url= http://www.chicagobusiness.com/cgi-bin/article.pl?page_id=1090 |title= 40 Under 40| work= [[Crain's Chicago Business]]| year= 2001| access-date= }}</ref> In 2003, she passed the final exam<ref name=mastersomm /> to become the youngest woman ever to achieve the rank of Master Sommelier.<ref name=food&wine>[http://www.foodandwine.com/articles/tastemakers-sommelier-prodigy-alpana-singh "Sommelier Prodigy - Alpana Singh"], Tastemakers profile at ''[[Food & Wine]]'', September 2003.</ref> (The master sommelier exam has an approximately 3% pass rate.<ref name=cbiz />)
Beginning at age 23, she served as sommelier at Chicago restaurant, Everest.<ref name=cbiz /> She later became Director of Wine and Spirits for [[Lettuce Entertain You Enterprises]], a large Chicago-based chain of restaurants.<ref name=mastersomm />
Singh became especially well known for hosting the local [[Public Broadcasting Service]] (PBS) [[public television]] station [[WTTW]]'s restaurant review show ''[[Check, Please!]]'' and her regular appearances on ''[[Chicago Tonight]]'' for the "Ask Alpana" segment on Thursday evenings. She replaced the original host of ''Check, Please!'', [[Amanda Puck]], in October 2003<ref name="venture audio" /> and remained in that role until 2013, when she was replaced by Catherine De Orio.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-05-29/entertainment/chi-check-please-host-20130528_1_david-manilow-alpana-singh-fig-tree 'Check Please!' names Catherine De Orio new host]</ref> In 2018, however, Singh was reported to be returning to the show, signing a two-year contract.<ref name= returning>{{cite news| url= https://chicago.eater.com/2018/5/23/17386232/check-please-alpana-singh-returns-host| title= Alpana Singh Says She’s Returning as ‘Check, Please’ Host| first= Ashok |last= Selvam| date= May 23, 2018| website= eater.com| publisher= Vox Media| access-date= July 21, 2018}}</ref>
Singh authored the 2006 book ''Alpana Pours: About Being a Woman, Loving Wine, and Having Great Relationships'' ({{ISBN|0-89733-546-5}}) and writes a column on wine for ''[[RedEye]]''.
In December 2012, Singh opened The Boarding House, a wine-driven concept in the [[River North]] neighborhood. The four-story restaurant received national attention from ''[[Forbes Travel Guide]]'' (Top 40 Tastemakers), ''[[Food & Wine]]'' (Sommeliers of the Year), ''[[Market Watch]]'', ''[[Sommelier Journal]]'', ''[[Restaurant Hospitality]]'', ''[[Midwest Living]]'' and others.{{cn|date= July 2018}} Additional accolades include "100 Best Wine Restaurants" (''[[Wine Enthusiast]]''), "Pastry Chefs to Watch" (''Time Out Chicago''), "2013 Best New Restaurants" (''[[Chicago Magazine]]''), and nominations for best restaurant design from the [[Eater Awards]] and [[Jean Banchet Awards]].{{cn|date= July 2018}} Singh closed out the restaurant’s first successful year with an all-female culinary and beverage team, and the honor of Sommelier of the Year 2013 Wine Star award from ''Wine Enthusiast''.{{cn|date= July 2018}}
In 2014 and 2015, Singh appeared as a judge on the [[Food Network]] television show ''[[Food Truck Face Off]]''. The television show premiered just prior to Singh running her first [[marathon]]{{cn|date= July 2018}} and opening her second restaurant, Seven Lions, an American concept, located on Chicago's [[Michigan Avenue (Chicago)|Michigan Avenue]].<ref name= "about squarespace 111714">{{cite web| deadurl= yes| url= http://alpanasingh.squarespace.com/aboutme/| title= About Me| website= alpanasingh.squarespace.com| date= | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20141117205101/http://alpanasingh.squarespace.com/aboutme/| archive-date= November 17, 2014| access-date= July 21, 2018}}</ref>
Singh sold her ownership in Seven Lions in October 2017 while preparing to run for public office (Cook County commissioner for the Third District), which she later decided against pursuing.<ref name= stake>{{cite news| url= http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20171025/BLOGS09/171029926/alpana-singh-sells-stake-in-seven-lions| via= chiagobusiness.com | date= October 25, 2017 |title= Alpana Singh sells stake in Seven Lions| first= Nona |last= Tepper | work= Crain's Chicago Business| access-date= July 21, 2018}}</ref> According to ''Eater'', Singh stated in July 2018 she sold ownership of both her restaurants The Boarding House and Seven Lions in October 2017.<ref name= shutters>{{cite news| title= Alpana Singh’s The Boarding House Shutters After $1.5 Million Back Rent Lawsuit| first= Ashok |last= Selvam| website= eater.com| publisher= Vox Media| date= July 18, 2018}}</ref> The Boarding House closed in July 2018. Singh still owns a third restaurant, Terra & Vine, in nearby [[Evanston, Illinois]].<ref name= returning /><ref name= shutters />
==Personal life== In 2006, Singh married fiction writer [[Charles Blackstone]];<ref name=mastersomm /> the couple divorced in 2014.<ref name= "about squarespace 112415">{{cite web| deadurl= yes| url= http://alpanasingh.squarespace.com/aboutme/| title= About Me| website= alpanasingh.squarespace.com| date= | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151124153215/http://alpanasingh.squarespace.com/aboutme/| archive-date= November 24, 2015| access-date= July 21, 2018}}</ref>
==Honors and accolades== *2006 Wine & Spirits Professional of the Year by ''[[Bon Appetit]]'' magazine *Best Sommelier in America by ''[[Wine & Spirits|Wine and Spirits]]'' magazine *''[[Crain Communications Inc.|Crain's Chicago Business]]'' 40 Under 40 *''Food & Wine'''s 35 Under 35 *Best Sommelier (2004) by ''[[Chicago (magazine)|Chicago]]'' magazine *30 Under 30 (2006) by ''[[Jane (magazine)|Jane]]'' magazine

{{other uses|Amenhotep}} {{Infobox person | name = Amenhotep | image = GD-EG-Louxor-126.JPG | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = Sculpture of Amenhotep, son of Hapu | birth_date = {{circa}} 1425 BC | birth_place = [[Athribis]], [[Lower Egypt]] | death_date = c. 1356 BC (aged c. 69) | death_place = [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]]?, [[Egypt]] | occupation = Polymath }}
'''Amenhotep, son of Hapu''' (transcribed ''jmn-ḥtp zꜣ ḥꜣp.w'';{{dubious|date=June 2018}} {{fl.}} early-mid 14th century BC) was an [[ancient Egypt]]ian [[architect]], a [[priest]], a [[scribe]], and a [[public official]], who held a number of offices under [[Amenhotep III]] of the [[Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt|18th Dynasty]].
== Life == He is said to have been born at the end of [[Thutmose III]]'s reign, in the town of [[Athribis]] (modern [[Banha]] in the north of [[Cairo]]). His father was Hapu, and his mother Itu.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wildung|first1=Dietrich|title=Egyptian Saints: Deification in Pharaonic Egypt|date=1977|publisher=New York University Press|isbn=0814791697|page=76|url=https://books.google.com.au/books/about/Egyptian_Saints.html?id=nvhfQgAACAAJ&redir_esc=y}}</ref> Though little about Amenhotep's early life is known prior to his entering civil service, it is believed that he learnt to read and write at the local library and scriptorium. He was a priest and a Scribe of Recruits (organizing the labour and supplying the manpower for the Pharaoh's projects, both civilian and military). He was also an architect and supervised several building projects, among them [[Amenhotep III]]'s mortuary temple at western [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]], of which only two statues remain nowadays, known as the [[Colossi of Memnon]], and the creation of the quarry of [[El-Gabal el-Ahmar]], nearby [[Heliopolis (ancient Egypt)|Heliopolis]], from which the blocks used to create the Colossi were probably taken. Other plans, such as the portico of the [[Temple of Karnak]], completed under [[Ramesses II]], and those for the [[Luxor Temple]] are also attributed to Amenhotep. He may also have been the architect of the Temple of [[Soleb]] in [[Nubia]].<ref name="Wilkinson2003">{{cite book|last=Wilkinson|first=Richard H.|title=The Complete Gods and Goddesses of Ancient Egypt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_eWNQgAACAAJ|year=2003|publisher=Thames and Hudson|isbn=978-0-500-05120-7|page=92}}</ref> Amenhotep is noted to have participated in Amenhotep III's first [[Sed festival]], in the 30th year of the king's rule. After this, he is believed to have retired from civil service and become the steward of Princess [[Sitamun]]'s properties (similar to an asset manager today), and received honours such as the designation of [[Fan-bearer on the Right Side of the King]], among other things. According to some reliefs in the tomb of [[Ramose]], he may have died in the 31st year of Amenhotep III, which would correspond to either 1360 BC or 1357 BC, depending on the [[Egyptian chronology|chronology]] used. His death has also been dated to the 35th year of the king. [[File:Amenhotep son of Hapu.jpg|thumb|right|Amenhotep, son of Hapu, as an elderly man. [[Egyptian Museum]], [[Cairo]].]]
== Legacy == After his death, his reputation grew and he was revered for his teachings and as a philosopher. He was also revered as a healer and eventually worshipped as a god of healing, like his predecessor [[Imhotep]] (the latter and Amenhotep being the only two commoners ever deified in the history of ancient Egypt). There are several surviving statues of him as a scribe, portraying him as a young man and as an older man. He was a deified human and thus was depicted only in human form. His cult was initially limited to the Thebes area, with a funerary temple constructed to him during his lifetime next to that of Amenhotep III. This was clearly an exceptional privilege, as it was the only private cult temple to be built among the royal monuments in the area. He continued to be worshipped for at least three centuries after his death, and evidence of this worship persists in a [[Twenty-sixth dynasty of Egypt|26th Dynasty]] votary inscription on a statue dedicated to Amenhotep by a daughter of the pharaoh.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mathstat.slu.edu/~bart/egyptianhtml/kings%20and%20Queens/Amenhotep-Hapu.html|title=Amenhotep son of Hapu |last=Bart |first=Anneke |date=September 2008 |website=slu.edu|publisher=Saint Louis University |access-date=20 December 2017 |quote=}}</ref> During the period of the [[Ptolemaic Kingdom]], his worship saw a resurgence which led to chapels being dedicated to him in the Temple of [[Hathor]] at [[Deir el-Medina]] and the [[Mortuary Temple of Hatshepsut]] at [[Deir el-Bahari]]. Statues were erected to him in the [[Temple of Amun]] at [[Karnak]] and he was treated as an intermediary with the god [[Amun]].<ref name="Wilkinson2003" /> Amenhotep also utilised his influence with the king to secure royal patronage for the town of Athribis, for the local god, and the temple dedicated to that god.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reshafim.org.il/ad/egypt/texts/amenhotep.htm |title=Inscriptions of Amenhotep, son of Hapu |last=Doffinger |first=André |date= |website=reshafim.org.il |publisher= |access-date=20 December 2017 |quote=}}</ref>
[[Manetho]] gives a legendary account of how Amenhotep advised a king named Amenophis, who was "desirous to become a spectator of the gods, as had Orus, one of his predecessors in that kingdom, desired the same before him". This Amenophis is commonly identified with [[Akhenaton]] also known as Amenhotep IV, while Orus fits with the latter's father, Amenhotep III. Manetho relates that the wise man counseled that the king should "clear the whole country of the lepers and of the other impure people" and that the King then sent 80,000 lepers to the quarries. After this the wise man foresaw that the lepers would ally themselves with people coming to their help and subdue Egypt. He put the prophecy into letter to the King and then killed himself. Manetho associates this event with the Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt, but Josephus strongly rejects this interpretation.<ref>Assmann J. (1997). ''Moses the Egyptian: The Memory of Egypt in Western Monotheism''. Harvard University Press. Cambridge. p. 30ff. {{ISBN|978-0674587397}}</ref>
===Mortuary temple=== Amenhotep was allowed to build his mortuary temple adjacent to that of the pharaoh. This honour is quite rare and indicates that Amenhotep was highly respected by the time of his death, despite the fact that he was a commoner and had only entered civil service at an advanced age, in his late forties. Excavated in 1934 or 1935, it measures 45 × 110 metres and is surrounded by three shrines. His first courtyard contained a 25 x 26 m water basin of considerable depth, fed by groundwater from the [[River Nile|Nile]]. Twenty trees were planted in pits around the basin. The temple at the end of the courtyard was adorned with a pillared [[portico]], and the temple was slightly elevated on a terrace.

}} '''Bambang Pamungkas''' (born 10 June 1980), also known as '''Bepe''', is an Indonesian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Persija Jakarta]] in the [[Liga 1 (Indonesia)|Liga 1]]<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.goal.com/kr/people/indonesia/25838/bambang-pamungkas| title= Bambang Pamungkas| publisher= Goal.com|}}</ref> and previously the [[Indonesia national football team]]. His natural position is [[Forward (association football)|striker]]. Bambang made his name in South East Asian football when he scored the only goal for Indonesia at the 2002 [[Tiger Cup]] semifinal against [[Malaysia]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/news/2002/December/27/thailand-indonesia-advance-to-tiger-cup-final/ |title=Thailand, Indonesia advance to Tiger Cup final |publisher=Soccerway |date=27 December 2002 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> and was the tournament's top scorer with eight goals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/asean02.html |title=ASEAN ("Tiger") Cup 2002 (Indonesia and Singapore) |publisher=Rsssf.com |date= |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref>
Bambang is considered to be an outstanding header of the ball, and has a reputation for sharpness in the penalty box. He is Indonesia's record holder in terms of both appearances and goalscoring, earning 86 caps and 38 goals<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/indo-recintlp.html Indonesia – Record International Players] (RSSSF)</ref> with the Indonesia national team,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/pamungkas-intl.html |title=Bambang Pamungkas – Goals in International Matches |author1=Mamrud, Robert |author2=Widigdo, Novianto |publisher=RSSSF |accessdate=15 June 2011 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110628204702/http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/pamungkas-intl.html| archivedate= 28 June 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref> and is perhaps the team's most popular player among its supporters.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid=1287232.html |title=Bambang, Indonesia's goalscoring pin-up |publisher=FIFA.com |date=19 August 2010 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> He was considered one of top ten Asian players of 2012 by [[ESPN FC|ESPN Soccernet]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story/_/id/1277602/top-ten-asian-football-players-of-2012?cc=4716| title= Top ten Asian players of 2012| publisher= [[ESPN FC|ESPN Soccernet]]|accessdate=28 December 2012| date=27 December 2012}}</ref>
==Club career== Bambang played for several clubs around his hometown as a youth, before beginning his senior career with [[Persija Jakarta]]. He was the club's top goalscorer in 1999–2000 [[Liga Indonesia Premier Division|Liga Indonesia]] with 24 goals. In 2000, he joined [[EHC Hoensbroek|EHC Norad]] in the Dutch Third Division. But after only 4 months he returned to Persija, the only Indonesian club he ever played for.
Bambang helped his club to win the Liga Indonesia in [[2001 Liga Indonesia Premier Division|2001]], and he was awarded the accolade of that season's best player. Persija Jakarta narrowly missed out on winning the championship again in [[2004 Liga Indonesia Premier Division|2004]] by one point. The following season Persija reached the [[2005 Liga Indonesia Premier Division|2005 final]], but lost 2–3 to [[Persipura Jayapura]].
Shortly afterwards Bambang accepted an offer to play in the Malaysian Football League with [[Selangor FA]], along with national teammate [[Elie Aiboy]]. In his first season in Malaysia he won the [[Premier League Malaysia]], [[FA Cup Malaysia]], and [[Malaysia Cup]], and became the league's top-scorer with 23 goals in 24 matches. During two seasons in Malaysia he scored 63 goals in four competitions: [[Malaysia Premier League]], [[Malaysia Super League]], [[FA Cup Malaysia]], [[Malaysia Cup]], [[AFC Cup]]. Despite having scored a total of 178 goals in [[Liga Indonesia]], like Singaporean forward [[Indra Sahdan Daud]], Bambang lost his place in the nation team to foreign-born talent.
In 2008, despite interests from English club [[Derby County]], he opted to stay in Indonesia.<ref>http://www.eyefootball.com/mobile/4572/Derby-Indonesian-star.html</ref>
In 2010, he had a trial at [[FC Ingolstadt 04]], but failed to secure a contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/news/2010/July/29/phoenix-sign-argentine-midfielder-cornejo/ |title=Phoenix sign Argentine midfielder Cornejo |publisher=Soccerway |date=29 July 2010 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref>
On 9 December 2013, he signed a one-year contract with Pelita Bandung Raya.
On 3 December 2014, he moved back to [[Persija Jakarta]].<ref>{{cite web|title=RESMI: Bambang Pamungkas Pulang Ke Persija Jakarta|url=http://www.goal.com/id-ID/news/1391/indonesia-super-league/2014/12/03/6722242/resmi-bambang-pamungkas-pulang-ke-persija-jakarta|accessdate=4 December 2014|language=Indonesian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espnfc.com/blog/football-asia/153/post/2190363/bambangs-return-to-persija-turns-the-clock-back-for-indonesian-fans |title=Bambang's return to Persija turns the clock back for Indonesian fans |publisher=[[ESPN]].com |author=Jason Dasey |date=11 December 2014 |accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref>
==International career== In 1998 Bambang's international career began when he was selected to play for the Indonesian youth team; his tally of seven goals in the Asian Cup U-19 Group V made him the competition's top scorer. He made his senior international debut the following year in a friendly match against [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]], in which he scored one goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bambangpamungkas20.com/bepe/karir/timnas |title=Bambang Pamungkas :[Official Website]: |publisher=Bambangpamungkas20.com |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> His total of 38 goals for his country make him the national team's highest-ever goalscorer.
Bambang has taken part in four [[FIFA World Cup qualification]] campaigns (2002, 2006, 2010 and 2014), playing in 14 matches and scoring 3 times.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/statisticsandrecords/players/player=182474/index.html |title=FIFA Player Statistics: Bambang PAMUNGKAS |publisher=FIFA.com |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> Bambang has also been involved in three [[AFC Asian Cup]]s: 2000, 2004 and 2007. He scored a goal against [[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]] in the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]], in a match Indonesia won 2–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/news/2007/July/10/indonesia-off-to-dream-start-at-asian-cup-after-beating-bahrain/ |title=Indonesia off to dream start at Asian Cup after beating Bahrain |publisher=Soccerway |date=10 July 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref>
In the [[2002 Tiger Cup]], Bambang was the top scorer with 8 goals, but an injury ruled him out of the Indonesian squad for the [[2004 Tiger Cup|2004 event]]. He scored twice in the [[2008 AFF Suzuki Cup]], once against [[Myanmar national football team|Myanmar]] and once against [[Cambodia national football team|Cambodia]]. In [[2010 AFF Suzuki Cup]] Bambang scored two goals in a match against Thailand, both from penalty kicks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.affsuzukicup.com/_webapp_739698/Indonesia_2_Thailand_1_-_Bambang_double_ends_Thai_hopes |title=Indonesia 2 Thailand 1 – Bambang double ends Thai hopes |publisher=Affsuzukicup.com |date=7 December 2010 |accessdate=26 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303213002/http://www.affsuzukicup.com/_webapp_739698/Indonesia_2_Thailand_1_-_Bambang_double_ends_Thai_hopes |archivedate=3 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> He has scored a total of 12 goals in the [[AFF Championship|ASEAN Football Championship]], making him the 5th-highest goalscorer in [[AFF Championship|ASEAN Football Championship]] history.
==Controversy== On 18 December 2011, following the match between [[Sriwijaya F.C.|Sriwijaya]] and [[Persija Jakarta]], Bambang, [[Ismed Sofyan]], and [[Leo Saputra]] were involved in an assault on [[Hilton Moreira]] at his hotel, allegedly provoked by Hilton's behaviour during the match.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://sindikasi.inilah.com/read/detail/1809572/bambang-pamungkas-ikut-pukuli-hilton |title=Bambang Pamungkas Ikut Pukuli Hilton |publisher=sindikasi.inilah.com |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref>
Bambang is one of the leading advocates for player welfare and rights in Indonesia.<ref>http://www.asianfootballfeast.com/2012/06/01/bambang-this-is-the-worst/</ref>
==Personal life== Bambang is married to Tribuana Tungga Dewi, with whom he has three daughters: Salsa Alicia, Jane Abel, Syaura Abana. The second youngest of 7 children. he initially had no thoughts of becoming a footballer. He likes reading and cooking, and has ambitions to become a teacher or a chef once his footballing career is over.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bambangpamungkas20.com/bepe/profil |title=Bambang Pamungkas :[Official Website]: |publisher=Bambangpamungkas20.com |accessdate=26 April 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426054326/http://bambangpamungkas20.com/bepe/profil |archive-date=26 April 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Bambang devotes some of his free time to charity work, promoting the Bambang Pamungkas Foundation that he set up to provide financial assistance and resources to schools in Indonesia. He is also involved in raising funds for children's cancer charities.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==Public figure== As a well-known public figure, Bambang has appeared in many product endorsements, including for Biskuat, Ti Phone, [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], Bodrex, and Kuku Bima.
Bambang has written a book in Bahasa Indonesia, ''Ketika Jemariku Menari'', relating his life, his career, and his teammates at club and national level, especially during the AFF 2010 campaign. Former Indonesia national team manager [[Ivan Venkov Kolev]] comments in the book that Bambang is "One striker rare in Indonesia. Commitment and professionalism are hallmarks of rare skill players in Indonesia".<ref name="His book">{{cite web |url=http://www.bukabuku.com/browse/bookdetail/81528/bepe20-ketika-jemariku-menari.html |title=Toko Buku Online – BEPE20: Ketika Jemariku Menari |publisher=BukaBuku.com |date=5 May 2011 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref>
==Summer Olympics== Pamungkas has been chosen as a torch bearer for [[2012 Summer Olympics]] flame passage through [[Calderdale]] on 24 June 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/news/local/olympic-route-through-calderdale-announced-1-4360953 |title=Olympic route through Calderdale announced – Local – Halifax Evening Courier |publisher=Halifaxcourier.co.uk |date=19 March 2012 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref>

Professor of Physical Education ('49–'75) | spouse = | children = | relatives = | school =Lindley High School | university =Stellenbosch University | website = }} '''Daniël Hartman Craven''' (11 October 1910 – 4 January 1993) was a South African [[rugby union]] player (1931–38), national coach, national and international rugby administrator, academic, and author. Popularly known as Danie, Doc, or Mr Rugby, Craven's appointment from 1949 to 1956 as coach of the Springboks signalled "one of the most successful spells in South African rugby history" during which the national team won 74% of their matches.{{cite book|title=Sports around the World|year=2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, Calif|isbn=9781598843002|page=150|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mYBtMajLAaAC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=Danie%20Craven&f=false|editor=John Nauright & Charles Parrish|accessdate=28 December 2013}} While as a player Craven is mostly remembered as one of rugby's greatest dive-passing [[Rugby union positions#scrumhalf|scrumhalves]] ever,{{cite web |title=2007 Inductee: Dr Danie Craven |url=http://www.irb.com/history/halloffame/newsid=2027696.html |work=IRB Hall of Fame |publisher=IRB.com |accessdate=28 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031023349/http://www.irb.com/history/halloffame/newsid%3D2027696.html |archivedate=31 October 2013 }} he had also on occasion been selected to play for the Springboks as a [[Rugby union positions#Centre|centre]], [[Rugby union positions#Fly-half|fly-half]], [[Rugby union positions#No.8|No.8]], and [[Rugby union positions#Full-back|full-back]]. As the longest-serving President of the [[South African Rugby Board]] (1956–93) and chairman of the [[International Rugby Board]] (1962, 1973, 1979), Craven became one of the best-known and most controversial rugby administrators.{{cite web|last=Nauright|first=John|title=Danie Craven|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/141989/Danie-Craven|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=Britannica.com|accessdate=28 December 2013}} Craven earned doctorates in [[ethnology]] (1935), [[psychology]] (1973) and [[physical education]] (1978). He not only created the physical training division of the [[South African Defence Force]] (1941) but became the first professor of physical education at [[Stellenbosch University]] (1949). == Early life and school years== Danie Craven was born on 11 October 1911 to James Roos Craven (b. 28 June 1882) and Maria Susanna Hartman (d. 1958) on Steeton Farm near [[Lindley, Free State|Lindley]], a small town on the [[Vals River]] in eastern [[Free State (province)|Free State province]] of [[South Africa]].{{cite web|last=Horne|first=Becky|title=Craven & Hayward Link|url=http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/SOUTH-AFRICA-EASTERN-CAPE/2006-05/1148800986|work=Rootsweb|publisher=Rootsweb.ancestry.com|accessdate=28 December 2013|date=28 May 2006}}{{cite web |url=http://www.property24.com/for-sale/lindley/lindley/free-state/9933/101383437?Branded=false |title=Archived copy |accessdate=28 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230233442/http://www.property24.com/for-sale/lindley/lindley/free-state/9933/101383437?Branded=false |archivedate=30 December 2013 }} Craven was the third of seven children. The family farm was named for [[Steeton, West Yorkshire|Steeton]] in [[West Yorkshire]], home to Craven's paternal grandfather, John Craven (1837–90), who came to South Africa as a diamond prospector.{{cite news|last=Bale|first=Steve|title=Obituary: Danie Craven|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-danie-craven-1476626.html|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=The Independent (London)|date=5 January 1993}} Craven later also named his home in [[Stellenbosch]] Steeton. His father, aged 18, fought against the British during the [[Anglo-Boer War]] and was interned in a British concentration camp, a fate that reportedly also befell his mother.{{cite web|last=Lord|first=David|title=How ‘Doc’ Craven laid the path for South African rugby|url=http://www.theroar.com.au/2011/02/24/how-doc-craven-laid-the-path-for-south-african-rugby/|work=The Roar|publisher=TheRoar.com|accessdate=28 December 2013|date=24 February 2011|quote=Comment by Spiro Zavos}}{{cite web|title=Prisoners of War – Craven, James|url=http://www.anglo-boer.co.za/database-search/result.php?section=Prisoners_of_War&fldIDUnique=10585#sectionHeader|work=Anglo-Boer.co.za|publisher=Anglo-Boer War Museum|accessdate=5 January 2014}} As a young boy Craven played barefoot soccer, and received his first lessons at a farm school. At the age of 13 he was sent to Lindley High School, and started playing rugby with a stone in the dusty town streets. At school he shone at cricket and rugby.{{cite news|last=Husselman |first=Herman |title=SA se rugbyreus word tagtig [SA rugby giant turns 80] |url=http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/1990/10/10/11/17.html |accessdate=31 December 2013 |newspaper=Die Burger |date=10 October 1990 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231235356/http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/1990/10/10/11/17.html |archivedate=31 December 2013 }} In the following year Craven was selected to play for the town's adult team, but his principal, Tivoli van Huyssteen, prevented him from playing until he turned 15.{{cite web|last=Le Roux |first=Herman |title=Sy eerste rugby was met 'n klip in 'n stofstraat [His first rugby was with a stone in a dirt road] |url=http://152.111.1.88/argief/berigte/beeld/1993/01/5/13/4.html |work=Beeld |publisher=Beeld (Johannesburg) |accessdate=28 December 2013 |date=5 January 1993 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230233750/http://152.111.1.88/argief/berigte/beeld/1993/01/5/13/4.html |archivedate=30 December 2013 }} Among his Lindley teammates was Lappies Hattingh, who would play with Craven 8 years later in the Springbok team against the [[Australia national rugby union team|Wallabies]]. == Education and teaching career== In 1929 Craven enrolled at [[Stellenbosch University]] in the [[Western Cape]]. He initially registered as a theology student, but later switched to [[Social Sciences]] and [[Social Anthropology]]. The switch was prompted by medical advice after his vocal chords were damaged by a kick to the throat while he tried to stop charging forwards during the 1932 test against Scotland. Craven lodged in [[Stellenbosch University halls of residence#Wilgenhof men's residence|Wilgenhof Men's Residence]], following in the footsteps of his maternal grandfather, George Nathaniel Hayward (1886–1977). In 1903 Hayward had been one of Wilgenhof's first residents.{{cite web|title=Noorspoort Guest Farm|url=http://www.noorspoort.co.za/page16.html|work=Noorspoort.co.za|accessdate=28 December 2013}} An all-round athlete, Craven represented his university in rugby, swimming (captain), water polo and baseball. He also participated in track and field, and played cricket, tennis, and soccer. Craven obtained his BA (1932) as well as a MA (1933) and PhD (1935) in [[Ethnology]] at Stellenbosch. His PhD dissertation was titled ''Ethnological classification of the South African Bantu''. His third doctorate was for his thesis on ''Evolution of Modern Games.''{{cite web|url=http://janiallan.com/facetoface/ |title=DR DANIEL HARTMAN CRAVEN : The Doctor Knows Best|first=Jani|last=Allan|authorlink=Jani Allan|work=janiallan.com|accessdate=19 June 2014}} He was appointed as Stellenbosch's first professor of Physical Education in 1949, and served in that capacity until 1975. After completing his education at Stellenbosch, Craven started teaching at [[St. Andrew's College (South Africa)|St. Andrew's College]] in [[Grahamstown]], [[Eastern Cape]], in 1936. He coached the school's rugby side, and while there he was selected for the 1937 Springbok tour.{{cite web|title=School Profiles – St Andrew's College|url=http://www.rugby365.com/article/38515-st-andrew-s-college|work=Rugby365.com|publisher=Rugby365.com|accessdate=29 December 2013}} Craven joined the Union Defence Force in 1938 as Director of Physical Education and was sent to Europe to study physical education in [[Germany]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Belgium]], [[Italy]], [[France]], and [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. The imminent outbreak of war forced the Cravens to return to South Africa. Craven was appointed head of physical education at the South African military academy with the rank of Major. When his section was established as a separate Physical Training Brigade in 1947, Craven was promoted to Lieutenant-Colonel and Director of the brigade. His military career was momentarily interrupted in 1947 as he was appointed lecturer in the Union Education Department at Stellenbosch University before returning to the brigade. Due to his fame as Springbok Craven's image was used in Afrikaans language newspapers during the Second World War to encourage men to enlist. The advertisement showed Craven in uniform, looking into the distance and announcing, 'I am playing in the biggest Springbok team ever; join me and score the most important try of your life.'{{cite journal| last = Grundlingh | first = Albert | title= The King's Afrikaners? Enlistment and Ethnic Identity in the Union of South Africa's Defence Force during the Second World War, 1939–1945 | journal = The Journal of African History| volume = 40 | number= 3 | pages = 351–365| year = 1999 | jstor = 183618 }} ==Rugby playing career== [[Image:Doc craven herdenking copy.jpg|thumb|100-year Anniversary of Doc Danie Craven at Wilgenhof men's residence in [[Stellenbosch]].]] At university Craven found a mentor in Stellenbosch coach and national selector [[August Frederick Markötter|A.F. ("Oubaas Mark") Markötter]], in charge of the university team from 1903 to 1957.{{cite news|title=Dit is Maandag 10 Junie, die 161ste dag [It is Monday 10 June, the 161th day] |url=http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/2002/06/10/15/10.html |accessdate=31 December 2013 |newspaper=Die Burger |date=10 June 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101102244/http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/2002/06/10/15/10.html |archivedate=1 January 2014 }} Markötter noticed Craven from the time he starting playing as a 19-year-old in 1929, and promoted him to the first team the following year. === Provincial career === Craven was selected as a Springbok in 1931 before he had made his provincial debut for Western Province in 1932. In a match against Free State in Bloemfontein that year he scored a hat-trick of tries in a performance regarded as one of his best. In 1936 he worked in [[Grahamstown]], and so started playing for Eastern Province, alongside Flappie Lochner. At Craven's suggestion, Markötter ensured that Lochner went on the 1937 tour to New Zealand. === International career === Craven played his first test match on 5 December 1931 as [[Scrum-half (rugby union)|scrum half]] at the age of 21 against {{nrut|Wales}} at [[St Helens, Merseyside|St Helens]], [[Swansea]]. His flyhalf was the captain, [[Bennie Osler]]. One of the other debutants that day was flanker André McDonald, who would later develop into the first specialist No. 8. Craven and McDonald became fast friends. His performance on a water-logged field led ''Die Burger'' to exult "Boy plays like a giant".{{cite book|last=Harris|first=Tim|title=Players: 250 Men, Women and Animals Who Created Modern Sport|year=2009|publisher=Random House|isbn=9780224082778}} In his third test, against Scotland at Murrayfield on 16 January 1932, Craven scored the winning try. The opportunity came because Craven implemented advice that he had received at Stellenbosch from coach Markötter. Markötter had said that on a muddy field a scrumhalf should either play with his forwards or kick, Craven recalled later. His advice enabled Craven to choose between captain Osler, who wanted the ball to be passed to him, and leader of the forwards [[Boy Louw]], who demanded that the ball stay with the forwards.{{cite web|last=Bezuidenhout|first=Kobus|title=Toe die Skotte bly was oor nul [When the Scots were happy with zero]|url=http://rugby.maroelamedia.co.za/2013/11/13/toe-die-skotte-bly-oor-nul/|work=Maroela Media|publisher=maroelamedia.co.za|accessdate=29 December 2013}} During the match he was knocked unconscious, sustained damage to his vocal chords, and lost a tooth. Craven's last test match was on 10 September 1938 as captain (also as [[Scrum-half (rugby union)|scrum half]]) at the age of 27 against the [[British and Irish Lions|British Lions]] at [[Newlands Stadium|Newlands]], [[Cape Town]]. During the 1930s he was one of the world's leading scrumhalves, but the start of the [[Second World War]] in 1939 ended his career prematurely. === Test history === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! ||Crusaders Grounds, Port Elizabeth |- | Great Britain || 16–21 ||Scrum-half (C)||-||10 September 1938 ||Newlands, Cape Town |- |} ==Rugby coaching and administration== ===Coaching career=== After his rugby-playing career ended, he was a national selector from 1938 until he was appointed coach in 1949. He started his coaching career with a bang, winning 10 matches in a row, including a 4–0 whitewash of New Zealand in their 1949 tour to South Africa. Under his guidance the Springboks were undefeated from 1949 to 1952, and won 17 of 23 tests (74% success rate) – an achievement that makes Craven one of South Africa's greatest coaches. He also coached Stellenbosch University from 1949 until 1956. === Administrative career === Craven became the president of the [[South African Rugby Board]] (SARB) in 1956. He was also a member of the [[International Rugby Board]] from 1957 and served as its chairman on several occasions. The last part of Craven's chairmanship of the SARB occurred during the country's most tumultuous years. Rugby had become the national sport of [[white South African]]s and a symbol of [[Afrikaner]] power. In the 1970s and 1980s, the outlawed [[African National Congress]] allied with overseas [[apartheid|anti-apartheid]] movements to successfully isolate South Africa from sporting and cultural contact with the rest of the world. Of all the sanctions aimed at South Africa, none irked the Afrikaner population more than the ban on rugby internationals.{{cite news|title=South Africa: The New Ball Game|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,968832,00.html?iid=chix-sphere|accessdate=29 December 2013|newspaper=Time Magazine|date=31 October 1988}} Craven managed to maintain links with other rugby playing nations during the years of South Africa's sporting isolation through his position with the IRB. He feared that isolation would negatively affect the standard of Springbok rugby. Consequently, he was not above "some murky business", such as the [[New Zealand Cavaliers]] tour in 1986, which Craven denied would happen. By the time South Africa returned to international competition in 1992, there had been no outgoing tours since 1981, and no incoming tours since 1984. In 1988 Craven met leaders of the [[African National Congress]] (ANC) in [[Harare]], [[Zimbabwe]] in a bold bid to return to global competition.{{cite web|title=Mister Rugby’s century|url=http://www.ruggaworld.com/2010/10/11/mister-rugbys-century/|work=Rugga World|publisher=RuggaWorld.com|accessdate=29 December 2013}} An unprecedented deal emerged to form a single rugby association that would field integrated teams for participation in foreign tournaments. Many right-wing white South Africans attacked Craven as a traitor for meeting with the ANC, and then-president [[P.W. Botha]] denounced the move. Although the deal did not lead to the immediate end of the sporting isolation, it paved the way for the formation of the unified body, the [[South African Rugby Union|South African Rugby Football Union]] (SARFU) in 1992. Craven was SARFU's first chairman until he died in 1993, having served for an unbroken 37 years at the head of South African rugby. ==Personal life== [[File:Danie Craven statue, Jannie Marais House.JPG|thumb|left|Statue of Danie Craven and Bliksem at [[Danie Craven Stadium|Coetzenburg]] in [[Stellenbosch]]]] Craven married twice. He wed Beyera Johanna (née Hayward, d. 2007{{cite web|last=Marx|first=Hester|title=Die Burger Oos-Kaap 2007 08 August|url=http://www.eggsa.org/newspapers/index.php/die-burger-oos-kaap/538-die-burger-oos-kaap-2007-08-august|work=eGGSA Library|publisher=eggsa.org|accessdate=29 December 2013|quote=+Woensdag 8 Aug. 2007 op Stellenbosch.}}) on 2 July 1938.{{cite news|last=Le Roux |first=Herman |title=Twintigjarige seun speel soos 'n reus in sy eerste toets [Twenty-year-old plays like a giant in his first test] |url=http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/1993/01/05/9/1.html |accessdate=29 December 2013 |newspaper=Die Burger |date=5 January 1993 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230232712/http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/1993/01/05/9/1.html |archivedate=30 December 2013 }} She was from the Eastern Cape, a teacher, and daughter of the member of parliament for [[Steytlerville]], George Hayward. Danie and Beyera had four children: Joan, George Hayward, Daniel, and James Roos Craven.{{cite web|title=Noorspoort Guest Farm|url=http://www.noorspoort.co.za/page13.html|work=Noorspoort.co.za|accessdate=28 December 2013}} One of his grandsons is the professional [[Namibia]]n road cyclist [[Dan Craven]], winner of the 2008 African Road Race Championships in Casablanca, Morocco. Danie and Beyera divorced in 1972.{{cite news|last=MacLeary|first=John|title=Dan Craven: Q&A|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/cycling/8017894/Dan-Craven-QandA.html|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=Telegraph (London)|date=9 October 2010}} On 30 May 1975 Craven married Martha Jacoba (Merlė) Vermeulen, the widow of Cape Town detective Dirk Vermeulen. Merlė worked in the fashion industry as a buyer for a chain of stores, and so had to attend fashion parades. After one such a parade in Pretoria, she twisted her ankle badly at her hotel. A bystander introduced her to Craven as "a doctor" who "knew a lot about ankle injuries". After Craven treated her foot, he telephoned and arranged to meet her again, and their relationship developed.{{cite news|last=Venter|first=Joe|title=Aan die sy van twee SA grótes [At the side of two of SA's great ones]|url=http://www.rapport.co.za/KaapRapport/Nuus/Aan-die-sy-van-twee-SA-grotes-20100410|accessdate=29 December 2013|newspaper=Rapport|date=4 October 2010}} Craven had a dog named "Bliksem" which accompanied him everywhere, even to rugby practices. A journalist recalled how "when Doc and BliksemThe name of the dog is somewhat ambivalent, as it can mean "lightning" or "rascal" in Afrikaans. In honour of Bliksem's loyalty and constant companionship, the dog is included as part of Craven's statue in Stellenbosch. were on the touchline at training, no one within sight would dare shirk".{{cite news|last=Henderson|first=Archie|title=Doc not entirely forgotten|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sport/rugby/2010/10/17/doc-not-entirely-forgotten|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=The Times (South Africa)|date=17 October 2010}} == Legacy == There were "many contradictions and convolutions in Craven's life", wrote Paul Dobson, which made him both admired and despised: :"His home language was [[Afrikaans]], but he would claim not to be an Afrikaner...a sportsman and yet he set higher store by academic achievement...accused of trying to hang on to an exclusively white preserve, and yet he devoted himself to breaking down racial barriers" {{cite book|last=Dobson|first=Paul|title=Doc – The life of Danie Craven|year=1994|publisher=Human & Rousseau|location=Cape Town|isbn=9780798133142}} === Honours === Danie Craven was accepted into the [[International Rugby Hall of Fame]] in 1997, the first of 9 South Africans to date.{{cite journal| last = Crawford | first = Scott A.G.M. | title= New Zealand rugby museum | journal = Journal of Sport History | volume = 23 | number= 3 | pages = 338–340 | year = 1996 | url = http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/JSH/JSH1996/JSH2303/jsh2303m.pdf }} In 2007 he became the third inductee into the [[IRB Hall of Fame]], only preceded by [[Rugby School]] and [[William Webb Ellis]], the alleged instigator of the game that would develop into rugby union. The South African [[Craven Week]] schools rugby competition is named after him, as well as the [[Danie Craven Stadium]] and Danie Craven Rugby Museum in Stellenbosch. To commemorate him, Stellenbosch University commissioned sculptor Pierre Volschenk to execute a bronze sculpture of Craven and his faithful dog. The statue stands within the grounds of the Coertzenburg sports complex in Stellenbosch.{{cite web|title=Prof. Pierre Volschenk |url=http://www.ridley.co.za/2009%20invite/2009-invite.htm |work=Sheena Ridley |publisher=Ridley.co.za |accessdate=28 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231001746/http://www.ridley.co.za/2009%20invite/2009-invite.htm |archivedate=31 December 2013 }} In 1981 Craven received the State President's Award for Exceptional Service, as well as the honorary citizenship of the city of Stellenbosch. He was made an honorary life president of the [[French Rugby Federation]] in 1992. === Aphorisms === Craven is often remembered for his quirky and controversial statements. For example, he said "When Maties and Western Province rugby are strong, then Springbok rugby is strong." Initially he was unsure that all South Africans could play together, arguing in 1968 that the different race groups were "separate nations...[who] won't ever play in the same side. But maybe...one day, we would have such a team".{{cite book|last=McRae|first=Donald|title=Winter Colours: Changing Seasons in World Rugby|year=2013|publisher=Mainstream Publishing|location=Edinburgh|isbn=9781840182477}} Craven denied that he had ever said that people of colour would be Springboks "over my dead body". His supporters could point to his liking for coloured rugby enthusiasts, and the efforts that he made over the last few years of his life to run multiracial rugby workshops in rural South Africa as signs that he had changed his views. === Published works === Apart from his academic dissertations which were referred to above, Craven wrote numerous books as solo and co-author on rugby, including his autobiography (1949), rugby terms for translators (1972), and how to organize a tennis club (1951). According to ''The Independent'' of London "his coaching manual ''Rugby Handbook'' (1970) is a standard". The titles listed below do not comprise an exhaustive list. {{colbegin}} ~. 1985 & 1986. ''Ons rugby op die platteland''. Parts 1 & 2. Nuweland: SA Rugbyraad. ~. 1980. ''Die groot rugbygesin van die Maties''. Kaapstad: Galvin & Sales. ~, and Tetsunosuke Ōnishi. 1979. Senshu to kōchi no tameno gendai ragubī no gijutsu to senpō. ~.1976. ''Rugby vir almal''. Kaapstad: Tafelberg-uitgewers. ~.1975. ''Rugby handbook''. Wellington, N.Z.: A.H. & A.W. Reed. ~.1974. ''Patroon vir rugby: 'n praktiese handleiding oor grondbeginsels, vaardighede, spelsette en oefenmetodes''. Kaapstad: Tafelberg. ~.1973. ''Spel as ondersteunende terapie in die behandeling van groep kroniese gehospitaliseerde psigiatriese pasiënte''. S.l: s.n.. ~, Chris Cillié, J. H. Jordaan, and H. J. Bothma. 1972. ''Rugbyterme: Eng.-Afr. 1,827 terme''. Johannesburg: Federasie van Afrikaanse Kultuurvereniginge. ~.1970. ''Rugby handboek.'' Kaapstad: Tafelberg. ~.[1960] 1970. ''Die verhaal van rugby.'' Johannesburg: Afrikaanse Pers. ~.1965. ''The seven pillars of rugby.'' Johannesburg: Swan Press. ~.1964. ''Springbok annale Springbok annals : internasionale toere na en van Suid-Afrika, 1891–1964.'' Johannesburg: Mimosa. ~.1961. ''Handleiding van rugby vir skole en klubs.'' Johannesburg: A.P.B. ~.1961. ''Springbok annals: international tours to and from South Africa, 1891–1958.'' Johannesburg: Mimosa. ~.1960. ''Enjoyment in the playing and training of rugby: Lekker rugby speel en oefen''. [S.l.]: South African Rugby Board. ~.1953. ''Danie Craven on rugby.'' Wellington [N.Z.]: Reed. ~.1951. ''Tennis vir die organiseerder''. Stellenbosch: UUB. ~.1954. ''Springbok story, 1949–1953''. Cape Town: R. Beerman. ~.1949. ''Ek speel vir Suid-Afrika.'' use ''Name (1950–present)'' --> | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Dor Bahadur Bista''' ([[Nepali language|Nepali]]: डोर बहादुर बिस्ट) (born ca. 1924-1926) is a [[Nepal]]ese [[anthropologist]], [[social scientist]] and [[activist]].<ref name="ecs">{{cite web|url=http://ecs.com.np/features/dor-bahadur-bista-the-father-of-nepalese-anthropology |title=Dor Bahadur Bista: The 'Father of Nepalese Anthropology' |publisher=ECS Nepal |date=9 July 2010 |accessdate=2017-04-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lalitmag.com/2014/03/1900/ |title=Dor Bahadur Bista’s last interview | la.lit |work=Lalit Magazine |date= |accessdate=2017-04-05}}</ref> Bista is considered the father of Nepalese anthropology, and has published such popular books as ''[[Fatalism and Development: Nepal's Struggle for Modernization]]'' and ''[[People of Nepal (book)|People of Nepal]]''. Bista [[List of people who disappeared mysteriously|mysteriously disappeared]] in 1995.
==Education== Sources vary regarding Bista's date of birth. Some say he was born around 1924,<ref name="republica"/> others in 1926.<ref name="ecs"/> He graduated from Patan High School, after which he attended [[Tri Chandra College]]. He completed his Certificate in Indian Ethnography in London.
==Career== While working as a government headmaster in a girls' high school in [[Patan district|Patan]], Bista became a research assistant to Professor Christoph Furer-Haimendorf of [[London University]] who was conducting field research in the area of Solukhumbu.<ref>http://digitalcommons.macalester.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1531&context=himalaya</ref> He later claimed that it was this experience that ignited his interest in Anthropology.
In 1972 he was sent to Lhasa in Tibet as Nepal's Counsel General.
He established an organization called Karnali Institute in [[Jumla (town)|Jumla]].
==Disappearance== In January 1995, Bista mysteriously disappeared from [[Jumla District]], being last seen boarding a bus to [[Chisapani]]{{disambiguation needed|date=April 2017}}<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nepalitimes.com/article/Nepali-Times-Buzz/Kesang-Tseten-documentary-on-Dor-Bahadur-Bista,2176 |title=Looking for Dor Bahadur Bista |first=Kunda |last=Dixit |work=Nepali Times |date=23 April 2015}}</ref> or [[Dhangarhi]].<ref name="ecs"/> His wife, Narayani, with whom he had a daughter and three sons, died soon after.<ref name="republica">{{cite web |url=http://admin.myrepublica.com/society/story/35232/man-to-who-pioneered-nepali-anthropology.html |work=MyRepublica |title=Man who pioneered Nepali anthropology |first1=Subhash |last1=Ghimire |first2=Guna Raj |last2=Luitel |date=18 January 2016 |accessdate=2017-04-05}}</ref>
The Association for Nepal and Himalayan Studies, which took over from the Nepal Studies Association of which Bista had been Honorary President, awards a prize named after him on an annual basis.<ref>{{cite web |title=Grants and Fellowship |publisher=Association for Nepal and Himalayan Studies |url=http://anhs-himalaya.org/grants-fellowship/ |accessdate=2017-04-05}}</ref>

{{Infobox officeholder | honorific_prefix = | name = Elaine Gumbs-Vlaun | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> | alt = | caption = | office = Member of the Cabinet of the [[Netherlands Antilles]] | term_start = | term_end = | monarch = [[Beatrix of the Netherlands]] | primeminister = | governor = [[René Römer]] | predecessor = | successor = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |70|2015|12|15}} | birth_place = | nationality = | party = | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | spouse = | partner = <!--For those with a domestic partner and not married--> | relations = | children = | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = <!-- may be used (optionally with father parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | father = <!-- may be used (optionally with mother parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | relatives = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | profession = Social worker | known_for = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | awards = <!-- For civilian awards - appears as "Awards" if |mawards= is not set --> | signature = | signature_alt = | website = }} '''Elaine Gumbs-Vlaun''' is a [[Sint Maarten|St. Maartener]] who was the first [[social worker]] on the island, and founded the Department of Social Services. She was also the first female parliamentarian, having served under the [[Netherlands Antilles]].
==Career== Elaine Gumbs-Vlaun founded the [[Sint Maarten]] department of Social Services, while acting as the island's original social worker. She was elected to the island council in 1983,<ref name=farewell/> and at the time was promoted as being the first woman to achieve that role, although [[Cornelia Jones]] predated her within the [[Windward Islands]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Miss Cornelia Jones First Woman Member of the Island Council.|url=https://thesabaislander.com/2014/02/22/miss-cornelia-jones-first-woman-member-of-the-island-council/|publisher=The Saba Islander|accessdate=26 November 2017|date=22 February 2014}}</ref> Gumbs-Vlaun also served as part of the Cabinet of the [[Netherlands Antilles]]. This made her the first Sint Maarten woman to be elected to a parliament.<ref name=farewell/><ref>{{cite news|title=Recognition for St. Maarten’s first social worker: Elaine Gumbs-Vlaun: "Do it with your heart and soul"|url=http://www.todaysxm.com/recognition-for-st-maartens-first-social-worker-elaine-gumbs-vlaun-do-it-with-your-heart-and-soul/|accessdate=26 November 2017|work=Today|date=19 March 2014}}</ref>
Gumbs-Vlaun was one of the founding members of the Mental Health Foundation in Sint Maarten in 2000, as part of a government initiative.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fitzpatrick|first1=Judy H.|title=A success story|url=http://thedailyherald.info/index.php?option=com_content&id=22057%3Aa-success-story-&Itemid=34|accessdate=26 November 2017|work=The Daily Herald|date=29 October 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105001753/http://thedailyherald.info/index.php?option=com_content&id=22057%3Aa-success-story-&Itemid=34|archivedate=5 November 2017}}</ref> In 2011, she became a member of the Social Economic Council (SER) and was reappointed in May 2014. Gumbs-Vlaun retired in 2015 upon reaching the age of 70. The chair of the SER, Oldine Bryson-Pantophlet, praised the work of Gumbs-Vlaun, saying that she kept her composure despite the sometimes heated discussions that would be held at the council.<ref name=farewell>{{cite news|title=SER bids farewell to member Elaine Gumbs-Vlaun.|url=http://smn-news.com/st-maarten-st-martin-news/20816-ser-bids-farewell-to-member-elaine-gumbs-vlaun.html|accessdate=26 November 2017|work=Sint Maarten News|date=15 December 2015}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name=George Vincent Fosbery |image= George Fosbery VC.jpg |caption= |birth_name= |birth_date=11 April 1832 |death_date= {{d-da|8 May 1907|11 April 1832}} |birth_place=[[Stert]], [[Wiltshire]] |death_place=[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], [[Bath and North East Somerset]] |placeofburial=St Mary's Cemetery, Bath |nickname= |allegiance={{UK}} |branch=[[British Indian Army]] |serviceyears=1852-1877 |rank=Lieutenant Colonel |unit=[[4th Bengal European Regiment]] |commands= |battles=[[Umbeyla Campaign]] |awards=[[File:Victoria Cross (UK) ribbon.png|30px]] [[Victoria Cross]] |relations= |laterwork=Firearms designer and inventor }} Lieutenant Colonel '''George Vincent Fosbery''' [[Victoria Cross|VC]] (11 April 1832 – 8 May 1907) was an [[England|English]] recipient of the [[Victoria Cross]], the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] forces. He was also a designer and inventor of firearms.
==Military background== An [[Eton College|Old Etonian]], Fosbery was 31 years old, and a [[lieutenant]] in the [[4th Bengal European Regiment]], [[British Indian Army]] during the [[Umbeyla Campaign]] during which he was awarded the Victoria Cross. He retired from the service in 1877 having achieved the rank of [[lieutenant colonel]].<ref name="obit">{{citation | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E03E5DD133EE033A2575AC0A9639C946697D6CF | title=LIEUT. COL. FOSBERY DEAD | newspaper=[[New York Times]] | place=original obituary archived on website | date=9 May 1907 | format=PDF | accessdate=3 December 2008}}</ref>
===Umbeyla Campaign=== {{See also|Henry William Pitcher}} On 30 October 1863 during the Umbeyla Campaign, North-West [[India]], Lieutenant Fosbery led a party of his regiment to recapture the [[Crag Picquet]], after its garrison had been driven in by the enemy and 60 of them killed. The approach to the Crag was very narrow but the lieutenant led his party with great coolness, and was the first man to gain the top of the Crag from his side of the attack. Subsequently, when the commanding officer was wounded, Lieutenant Fosbery assembled a party and pursued the routed enemy, inflicting on them further losses.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=22988|page=3425|date=7 July 1865}}</ref> [[File:Fosbery grave.jpg|thumb|Fosbery's grave, [[Smallcombe Cemetery]], Bath]]
==Inventions== In 1895 he patented a design for a self-cocking revolver, which was taken up by the Webley & Scott Revolver & Arms Company. The [[Webley-Fosbery Automatic Revolver]] was produced as a six-shot .455 caliber and an eight-shot .38 caliber.
Sometime in the late 19th century he invented the [[Paradox gun]].<ref name="obit"/> A gun made by [[Holland & Holland]], so named because only the front two inches of the barrel were rifled; intended to be used as both rifle and shotgun, capable of firing both shot and conical bullets with accuracy.
==Medals== In 1997, Fosbery's Victoria Cross was sold at an Alberta auction for $45,000. His medals are now on display in the Lord Ashcroft Gallery in the [[Imperial War Museum]] in London.<ref name="Ashcroft">{{cite web | url=http://www.victoriacross.org.uk/vvashcr2.htm | title=Lord Ashcroft VC collection | accessdate=March 4, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[[File:Fosbery grave 2.jpg|thumb|Recent (March 2016) photo of Fosbery's grave]][http://fosbery.tripod.com/GVF.html Biography] {{Portal|Biography}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20041028141858/http://www.homeusers.prestel.co.uk/stewart/avon.htm Location of grave and VC medal] ''(Avon)'' * {{Find a Grave|7830246}}

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = George Johann Klein | honorific_suffix = OC, OBE | image = <!-- George Klein.JPG --> | image_size = | alt = George J. Klein | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1904|08|15}} | birth_place = [[Hamilton, Ontario]], Canada | death_date = {{Death date and age|1992|11|04|1904|08|15}} | death_place = [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | other_names = | ethnicity = <!-- Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | citizenship = | education = [[University of Toronto]] | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | known_for = Invention of the [[Canadarm]], [[power wheelchair]], microsurgical [[staple gun]], [[ZEEP]] nuclear reactor | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | awards = [[Canadian Science and Engineering Hall of Fame]] inductee, [[Order of Canada]], [[Order of the British Empire]] | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | footnotes = | box_width = }} [[File:Klein_Drive_Chair_1953.jpg|thumb|right|George Klein (back) and his electric wheelchair 1953]] '''George Johann Klein''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|OC|MBE}} (August 15, 1904 – September 4, 1992) was a [[Hamilton, Ontario]]-born [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[inventor]] who is often called the most productive inventor in Canada in the 20th century. Although he struggled as a high school student, he eventually graduated from the [[University of Toronto]]. His inventions include key contributions to the first electric [[wheelchair]]s for [[quadriplegia|quadriplegic]]s, the first microsurgical [[staple gun]], the [[ZEEP]] [[nuclear reactor]] which was the precursor to the [[CANDU reactor]], the international system for classifying ground-cover [[snow]], [[aircraft ski]]s, the Weasel [[all-terrain vehicle]], the STEM antenna for the space program, and the [[Canadarm]].
Klein worked for forty years as a mechanical engineer at the [[National Research Council of Canada]] laboratories in Ottawa (1929–1969).<ref>Bourgeois-Doyle 2004, p. 232.</ref>
In 1968, he was made an [[Order of Canada#Officer|Officer of the Order of Canada]]. In 1995, he was inducted to the [[Canadian Science and Engineering Hall of Fame]].<ref>[http://www.sciencetech.technomuses.ca/english/about/hallfame/u_i19_e.cfm The Canadian Science and Engineering Hall of Fame: George J. Klein], Canada Science and Technology Museum.</ref>
