{{Infobox person | name = Guillermo Carlos Cazenave | image = | caption = Cazenave with [[Anthony Phillips]] of [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|09|18}} | birth_place = [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina | occupation = {{hlist|Musician|record producer|composer}} | module = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | instrument = guitar, keyboards, drums | genre = {{hlist|[[New-age music|New-age]]|[[Folk music|folk]]|[[Afro/Cosmic music|cosmic]]|[[space music]]}} | years_active = 1969–present | label = RTVEMúsica
Astral Music | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Anthony Phillips]]|[[Litto Nebbia]]|[[Steven Halpern]]|[[Ronald Lloyd]]|Jeremy Morris}} | website = {{URL|guillermocazenave.com}} }} }} '''Guillermo Carlos Cazenave''' (born September 18, 1955 in [[Buenos Aires]]) is an Argentine musician who has been living in Europe for more than three decades. He is also known as Guill Cazenave. He is also an author and journalist, specialized in many different musical styles. == Early years == Guill started making music from a very young age; when he was 7, his grandmother from the [[Isle of Skye]] gave him a bagpipe. In 1963, his older siblings travelled to New York. A while later they returned to [[Argentina]] with the first albums by the [[Beatles]], and Guillermo, after seeing the band [[The Dave Clark Five]] on television, started playing the drums in 1965, later to study with the drummer and percussionist Sam Lerman. In 1969, Guillermo started his first pop band with two classmates from the [[Colegio Cardenal Newman]] in Buenos Aires, making his debut with a performance at a party, in September of the same year. At the same time, he continued his drumming studies with the recognised master [[Alberto Alcalá]], percussionist of the Orchestra of the [[Teatro Colón]], to continue experimenting with other different styles under the teachings of Droopy Gianello, drummer of [[Arco Iris (band)|Arco Iris]], a folk-rock band led by [[Gustavo Santaolalla]]. Cazenave recorded his first songs using his brother's Toshiba 2 track tape recorder. It was with it that he recorded several of his demos, using guitar, flute and his voice, in a Celtic-folk style, probably influenced by his beginnings playing the bagpipes. In 1973, Guillermo Cazenave graduated from high school and travelled to the US where he continued composing and recording songs both in Spanish and English, thanks to his bilingual studies at the Newman College. In 1974, back in Buenos Aires, he made his first professional recording at the ION Recording Studios, with the pianist Antonio Marzochi and the guitarist Kelo Palacios, for a play that was performed for the first time at the [[Teatro San Martín|San Martín Theatre]]. Not long after that, Guill returned to New York, and stayed there until May 1977, when he emigrated to Europe, staying for long periods of time between London and [[Sitges]], where he established contact and made friends with musicians such as [[Anthony Phillips]] and [[Miguel Abuelo]]. == From folk and pop to space music == In [[Sitges]] in 1983, Guill created the first Spanish [[new age]] music record label, and started selling his music on magazines like [[Integral]], Karma 7 and [[Popular 1]]. Between 1984 and 1999, Guillermo Cazenave produced more than 50 albums and sold around 300,000 copies of his work, mainly in the alternative market. It was very common to find him at congresses, symposiums and festivals. He often appeared on the Spanish media, and travelled and performed in countries such as France, England, US or [[Mexico]]. In the late 90s, he relocated to the Cathar Country in the South of France, near [[Montségur]], and began a period of temporary retirement with just the occasional appearance, and few CDs released. In 2007, after an impasse of several years, he reappeared with his album Ser, and with the novel "La Noche del Grial" ("The Night of the Grail"), with prologues by Jean-Luc Robin and [[Javier Sierra]], in which he narrates his experiences in that area. In 2008, Cazenave started performing live again, giving talks at congresses, recording new albums, writing for magazines like Más Allá de la Ciencia (Beyond Science), where he managed the music section, or in Universo Holístico (Holistic Universe), and appearing on radio programs like Espacio en Blanco, by his friend Miguel Blanco Medrano, in the Spanish national radio ([[Radio Nacional de España]]), in a section called From the Cathar Country. Cazenave has recorded with renowned musicians in different styles and tendencies, such as the British oboist Ronald Lloyd; the ex member of [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]] and guitarist [[Anthony Phillips]], the pop musician [[Jeremy Morris]], the rock pioneer in Argentina [[Litto Nebbia]], and many other skilled artists and friends. The diversity of his work, which includes [[new age]], [[pop-rock]], [[Celtic fusion]] and even classical music, makes Guill's career and style difficult to classify. His production currently goes beyond one thousand registered pieces, and more than 80 albums in the market, as well as several books and innumerable video productions. == The musician of the spheres == Cazenave's music has already travelled through space during the last trip of the [[Shuttle Endeavour|NASA Shuttle Endeavour]], on May 16, 2011. His "Fly High" was one of the pieces chosen by the astronauts and technicians. During the last trip of the Endeavour Shuttle, with the mission of installing some equipment to receive radiation from outer space and investigate the origins of the universe; the six astronauts in the crew of the spaceship, along with numerous [[NASA]] technicians, selected 50 musical compositions to take and listen to during the trip. The trip itself had a very special meaning, not only because it was the final flight of the emblematic shuttle, and because of the characteristics of the mission, but also because of the general idea of leaving the footprint of human expression in space through one of its most sublime arts: music. Among greatest hits and classics of all times, like [[What a Wonderful World|Wonderful World]] by [[Louis Armstrong]], [[Imagine (John Lennon song)|Imagine]] by [[John Lennon]] and unforgettable songs by [[U2]], [[Rolling Stones]] and other English-speaking countries, they selected "Fly High" (Vuela Alto) by the musician Guillermo Cazenave, composed in 1996 for his album "Here" (Aquí). Cazenave also receive a diploma from the NASA, along with a few congratulating lines by John Shannon, Program Manager of the Space Shuttle, saying: “You are now, with your music, part of the rich history of our program since the times of the Apollo.” == Author == As a writer, these are some of his most recent books: La Noche del Grial (The Night of the Grail, currently in the process of being translated into English),{{citation needed|reason=the author Nieve Andrea is currently working on this|date=April 2016}} published by Mandala Ediciones (Madrid), Música para una Nueva Era (Music for a New Age) by Kier (Buenos Aires), or El Sonido del Universo (The Sound of the Universe), with its two first editions being published by Indigo in [[Barcelona]]. == Discography == * ''Contando Lejanos Tiempos'' * ''Demos-Le'' * ''Un Espacio Más'' * ''Dos Espacios Más'' * ''Vivo Vien'' * ''Era Buena'' * ''The Meadows of Englewood'' (with Anthony Phillips) * ''Spanish Impromptu'' (with Steven Halpern) * ''BBC & Radio 3 Recordings'' * ''Tower'' * ''Aquí'' * ''Two Suns'' (with Jeremy Morris) * ''All Our Lives'' (with Anthony Phillips) * ''Pack'' * ''Parthenon'' (with Ronald Lloyd) * ''Duplex'' (duets with friends) * ''Ser'' * ''Two Seconds'' (with Jeremy Morris) * ''Guita-Ra'' === Notes === {{reflist}} == References == *"Radio nacional de España". *The waiting room online http://www.twronline.net/issues/twr33/twr33_englewood.htm *Psychedelic Centralhttp://psychedeliccentral.com/psychedelicgaragesurf/cazenavemorris.html == External links == * [http://www.guillermocazenave.com Official Site] * [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCm34907AIpHsHHMJJFbFbNA Official Youtube Channel] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cazenave, Guillermo Carlos}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Argentine composers]] [[Category:New-age musicians]] [[Category:People educated at Colegio Cardenal Newman]]

{{Use Indian English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} [[File:Horigopal Bal.jpg|thumb|Harigopal Bal]] '''Harigopal Bal''' or '''Baul''' ({{lang-bn|হরিগোপাল বল}})popularly called as Tegra (died 22 April 1930) was a [[Bengali people|Bengali]] revolutionary who took part in revolutionary activities against British rule in [[British India|India]].
Bal was born in the village Kanungopara in [[Chittagong District|Chittagong]], [[Bengal]] (now in [[Bangladesh]]). His father was Pran Krishna Bal. Harigopal Bal joined the revolutionaries and took part in the [[Chittagong Armoury Raid]] on 18 April 1930 with his elder brother [[Lokenath Bal]]. After the abortive raid, Bal escaped. Four days later, he was injured after being shot while fighting against British troops on Jalalabad Hill, near Chittagong. He died on 22 April 1930.
== Film adaptations == A film ''[[Chittagong (film)|Chittagong]]'' released in October 2012, directed by Dr. [[Bedabrata Pain]], shows role of Harigopal Bal (called by his nickname "Tegra" in the movie) in the Chittagong Armoury raid. [[Manoj Bajpai]] was the lead actor and played the role of [[Surja Sen|Surya Sen]].
Actor Nitin Prabhat played the Harigopal Bal with nickname 'Tegra' in the bollywood movie [[Khelein Hum Jee Jaan Sey]] released in 2010.
== References == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061231120404/http://www.aicc.org.in/some_prominent_martyrs_of_%20india%E2%80%99s_freedom_struggle.php Some prominent martyrs of India's freedom struggle]

{{Use British English|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox noble | name = The Earl of Harewood | image = Henry Lascelles, Earl of Harewood.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date|1882|9|9|df=y}} | birth_place = [[London]], [[England]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1947|5|24|1882|9|9|df=y}} | death_place = [[Harewood House]], [[Yorkshire]] | burial_date = 27 May 1947 | burial_place = All Saints Church, [[Harewood]], [[Yorkshire]] | father = [[Henry Lascelles, 5th Earl of Harewood]] | mother = Lady Florence Bridgeman | spouse = {{marriage|[[Mary, Princess Royal and Countess of Harewood|Mary, Princess Royal]]|28 February 1922}} | issue = {{plain list| * [[George Lascelles, 7th Earl of Harewood]] * [[Gerald David Lascelles|Gerald Lascelles]] }} | reign = 6 October 1929 – 24 May 1947 | reign-type = Tenure | succession = }} '''Henry George Charles Lascelles, 6th Earl of Harewood''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|KG|GCVO|DSO|TD|JP|DL}} (9 September 1882 – 24 May 1947), styled '''''The Honourable'' Henry Lascelles''' before 1892 and '''Viscount Lascelles''' between 1892 and 1929, was a British [[soldier]], peer and a [[Yorkshire]] [[landowner]]. He was the husband of [[Mary, Princess Royal and Countess of Harewood|Mary, Princess Royal]], and through her the son-in-law of [[King George V]] and [[Mary of Teck|Queen Mary]] and a brother-in-law to [[Edward VIII]] and [[George VI]]. ==Family== Lascelles was the son of [[Henry Lascelles, 5th Earl of Harewood]] and Lady Florence Bridgeman, daughter of [[Orlando Bridgeman, 3rd Earl of Bradford]]. He was born at the London home of his maternal grandfather, 43 Belgrave Square.{{cite book|title=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Volume 32|year=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=592|isbn=0-19-861382-2}} Article by H.E. Wortham, revised by K.D. Reynolds. [[File:Viscount Lascelles & wife.jpg|thumb|left|Wedding portrait of Princess Mary and Viscount Lascelles, 1922]] Lord Harewood married [[Mary, Princess Royal and Countess of Harewood|Princess Mary]], only daughter of [[King George V]] of the United Kingdom and [[Mary of Teck|Queen Mary]], at [[Westminster Abbey]], on 28 February 1922. His best man was [[Sir Victor Mackenzie, 3rd Baronet]].{{cite web|title='The Wedding of 6th Earl of Harewood and Princess Mary'|url=http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw196517/The-Wedding-of-6th-Earl-of-Harewood-and-Princess-Mary|publisher=[[National Portrait Gallery, London]]|accessdate=25 September 2015}} It was later reported that Lascelles proposed to her after a wager at his club.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/aug/30/ivanka-trump-princess-royal-america-princess-anne|title=Sorry, Ivanka Trump: you make a pretty poor Princess Royal|publisher=The Guardian|first=Peter|last=Bradshaw|date=30 August 2017|accessdate=30 May 2018}} After their marriage, Lord and Lady Harewood split their time between their homes; Chesterfield House (destroyed after the Second World War) in London, [[Goldsborough Hall]], at Harwood Estate and [[Harewood House]] itself, in Yorkshire, which became their family home in 1929. They had two children: * [[George Lascelles, 7th Earl of Harewood|George Henry Hubert Lascelles, 7th Earl of Harewood]] (born at Chesterfield House 7 February 1923 – died 11 July 2011) and christened at St Mary's Church [[Goldsborough, North Yorkshire|Goldsborough]] 25 March 1923 * [[Gerald David Lascelles|The Hon. Gerald David Lascelles]] (born at [[Goldsborough Hall]] 21 August 1924 – died 27 February 1998) Her elder son, the Earl of Harewood, wrote about his parents' marriage in his memoirs ''The Tongs and the Bones'' and says that "they got on well together and had a lot of friends and interests in common". ==Military career== After education at [[Eton College]], Lascelles attended the [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst]] before being commissioned as a [[Second Lieutenant]] into the [[Grenadier Guards]] on 12 February 1902,{{London Gazette|issue=27405|page=846|date=11 February 1902}} serving until 1905.{{cite book|title=Kelly's Handbook to the Titled, Landed and Official Classes, 1918|publisher=Kelly's|page=928}} He was an honorary attache at the British Embassy in [[Paris]] from 1905 until 1907, then served as aide-de-camp to the [[Governor General of Canada]], Earl Grey, until 1911. In 1913 he joined the [[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]] as Second Lieutenant in the [[Yorkshire Hussars Yeomanry]]. He was promoted [[Lieutenant (British Army)|Lieutenant]] on the Reserve of Officers in 1914. He continued with the yeomanry after the outbreak of the [[First World War]] until he rejoined the Grenadier Guards for service on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in April 1915. Even so he continued to be promoted within the regiment to [[Captain (British Army)|Captain]] in 1917.{{cite book|title=Kelly's Handbook, 1920|publisher=Kelly's|page=976}} Postwar he was promoted [[Major (British Army)|Major]] in 1920 and retired in 1924.{{cite book|title=Kelly's Handbook, 1929|publisher=Kelly's|page=814}} Entry under Viscount Lascelles (published before succession to earldom same year). Meanwhile, at the front, he was wounded in the head at the [[Second Battle of Givenchy]] but recovered to fight in the [[Battle of Loos]] in 1915, and was wounded a further two times as well as gassed. He was promoted Captain and later Major in command of a battalion (the 3rd) in 1915, and [[Lieutenant-Colonel]] in 1918. He was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] (D.S.O.) and a bar both in 1918, as well as the [[Croix de Guerre 1914-1918 (France)|French Croix de Guerre]]. He continued his interest in the Territorial movement after the war, as Honorary Colonel of the 1st Battalion The London Regiment from 1923, the 5th Battalion [[West Yorkshire Regiment]] from 1937, and as President of the West Yorkshire Territorial Forces Association from 1928. He was also appointed in 1937 Honorary [[Air Commodore]] of the 609 (West Riding) Bomber Squadron of the [[Auxiliary Air Force]].{{cite book|title=Kelly's Handbook, 1945|publisher=Kelly's|page=895}} ==Other interests== After the war, Lascelles remained interested in local [[Yorkshire]] issues and events, often contributing to the Leeds Board of Management. He was president of the Yorkshire Rural Community Council.{{cite news|title=Lord Harewood|url=http://www.genesreunited.com.au/searchbna/results?memberlastsubclass=none&searchhistorykey=0&keywords=board%20management%20middleton%20harewood&county=west%20yorkshire%2c%20england|date=13 March 1943 |work=Yorkshire Post and Leeds Intelligencer |location=West Yorkshire, England|accessdate=25 September 2015|quote=... Lord Harewood, speaking on the report of the Board of Management, said was impressed the Increase last .. (Also, 28 March 1929...BOARD OF MANAGEMENT. Mr. Middleton re-elected ...(as) treasurer, and the following governors were appointed to form the Board Management in connection ...)}}{{cite news|title=Lord Harewood's Letter|url=http://www.genesreunited.com.au/searchbna/results?memberlastsubclass=none&searchhistorykey=0&keywords=noel%20middleton%20harewood&county=west%20yorkshire%2c%20england&from=1900&to=1949|date=12 April 1937 |work= Yorkshire Post and Leeds Intelligencer |location=West Yorkshire, England|accessdate=25 September 2015|quote=Lord Harewood's Letter Lord Bolton then read a letter from Lord Harewood. president of the Yorkshire Rural Community Council...}} He was Lord Lieutenant of the West Riding of Yorkshire from 1927 until his death. He was President of the [[Royal Agricultural Society of England]] in 1929 when that year's [[Royal Show]] was held at [[Harrogate]]. Interested in equestrian sports, he served as Master of the Bramham Moor Hounds from 1921,, was a steward of the [[Jockey Club]], and co-editor of ''Flat Racing'' (1940) for the London Library. Lord Harewood, a [[Freemasonry|Freemason]], served as [[Grand Master (Masonic)|Grand Master]] of the [[United Grand Lodge of England]] from 1942 to 1947.{{cite web|url=http://freemasonry.london.museum/it/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/Standards-and-Banners-in-Freemasonry-_2_.pdf|title=A Library and Museum of Freemasonry Information Leaflet: The Use of Standards and Banners in Freemasonry|publisher=The Library and Museum of Freemasonry|date=November 2011|accessdate=16 May 2018}} ==Political== As Viscount Lascelles, he attempted to enter the [[House of Commons (United Kingdom)|House of Commons]] when he stood at a [[Keighley by-election, 1913|by-election]] in 1913 as [[Unionist Party (UK)|Unionist]] candidate for [[Keighley (UK Parliament constituency)|Keighley]], held when its incumbent [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] Member of Parliament, [[Stanley Buckmaster, 1st Viscount Buckmaster|Sir Stanley Buckmaster]] was appointed [[Solicitor General of England and Wales|Solicitor General]]. In the three-cornered fight that also included a [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] candidate, he came second to Buckmaster by 878 votes. He did not seek election again and his defeat led to a later distaste for politics. He declared in later life "every war in which Britain had been involved had been due to the inefficiency of politicians, and they began what soldiers had to end". On succeeding to his father's Earldom he became a member of the [[House of Lords (UK)|House of Lords]]. ==Death and legacy== Lord Harewood died of a heart attack on 24 May 1947 at the age of 64 at his home, [[Harewood House]]. Lady Harewood, the Princess Royal, survived him by almost eighteen years and died in 1965. It is widely understood that [[Virginia Woolf]] based the character of Archduke Henry on him in her novel [[Orlando: A Biography|''Orlando'']], a tribute to her lover [[Vita Sackville-West]]. Henry Lascelles was one of West's suitors.{{cite web|url=http://www.sparknotes.com/lit/orlando/canalysis.html|website=sparknotes.com|title=Orlando|accessdate=25 September 2015}} ==Titles, styles, honours and arms== ===Styles=== * 1882–1892: ''The Honourable'' Henry G. C. {{Infobox person |name = Iris Bannochie |image = Iris Bannochie.jpg |caption = |birth_date = 1914 |birth_place = [[Grenada]] |death_date = 1988 |death_place = [[Barbados]] |other_names = |known_for = Gardening |occupation = Horticulturist |nationality = [[Barbados|Barbadian]] }}
'''Iris Bannochie''' (1914 – September 1988) was a [[Barbados|Barbadian]] [[horticulturalist]] who was the leading expert on [[horticulture]] on the island of [[Barbados]].
==Life== Bannochie was born in [[Grenada]] in 1914 and, apart from her early childhood, lived all her life in Barbados. She married John Mackie Bannochie on 13 April 1964. She was a founding member of the Barbados National Trust.
[[File:Andromeda Botanical Gardens 11.jpg|thumb|left|Headstones of Iris and John Bannochie in Andromeda Gardens]] With her second husband, John, she created and owned [[Andromeda Gardens]], a scenic park with [[flowering plant]]s and [[tropical]] [[trees]] in the village of [[Bathsheba (Barbados)|Bathsheba]], [[Saint Joseph, Barbados|Saint Joseph]] in [[Barbados]]. Bannochie founded the garden around 1954 on {{convert|8|acre|m2}} of land that had been in her family since 1740.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Leach | first = John | title = Tourism For Survival | journal = Roots | volume = 1 | issue= 1 | date = April 2004 | url = http://www.bgci.org/education/article/0408/ | accessdate =2008-03-10}}</ref> On Bannochie's death, Andromeda Gardens was left to the [[Barbados National Trust]].
In 1977, she was awarded [[the Veitch Memorial Medal]] by the [[Royal Horticultural Society]] for her contribution to tropical horticulture.<ref>{{cite book | last = Bannochie | first = Iris |author2=Marilyn Light | title = Gardening in the Caribbean | publisher = Macmillan | year = 1993 | isbn = 0-333-56573-8}}</ref> Bannochie suffered a [[stroke]] in the summer of 1988 and died shortly afterwards.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Deitz | first = Paula | title = A Rare Garden in Barbados | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = 1991-02-17 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE4DF133CF934A25751C0A967958260&scp=1&sq=A+Rare+garden+in+barbados&st=nyt}}</ref> She was 73 years old.
A [[heliconia]] [[cultivar]] is named after Bannochie - ''[[Heliconia stricta]]'' 'Iris Bannochie'.<ref>{{cite web| title = Heliconia Photos | date = 2004-04-29 | url = http://andromeda.cavehill.uwi.edu/heliconia_photos.htm | accessdate =2008-03-10}}</ref>
==References== <!--See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes for an explanation of how to generate footnotes using the <ref> and </ref> tags and the tag below --> {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://andromeda.cavehill.uwi.edu/Heliconia%20photos/heliconia%20Iris%20B%206inch.JPG Photograph of Heliconia stricta 'Iris Bannochie']

{{Infobox scientist | name = Ivan Bjerre Damgård | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = 1956 | birth_place = | residence = | nationality = [[Denmark]] | field = [[Cryptography]] | work_institution = [[Aarhus University|Department of Computer Science, Aarhus University]] | alma_mater = [[Aarhus University]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Peter Landrock]] | doctoral_students = [[Lars Knudsen]]
[[Ronald Cramer]] | known_for = {{Unbulleted list|[[Merkle–Damgård construction]]|[[Damgård–Jurik cryptosystem]]}} | awards = [[International Association for Cryptologic Research|IACR Fellow]] (2010) }} '''Ivan Bjerre Damgård''' (born 1956) is a [[Danish people|Danish]] cryptographer and currently a professor at the Department of Computer Science, [[Aarhus University]], [[Denmark]]. In 1983, he obtained a master's degree in [[mathematics]] (with minors in [[music]] and [[computer science]]) at Aarhus University. He began his PhD studies in 1985 at the same university, and was for a period a guest researcher at [[Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica|CWI]] in Amsterdam in 1987.{{cite web |url=http://www.win.tue.nl/wsk/eidma/courses/minicourses/damgaord/MC-00-23.html |title=MC-00-23 |work=Cryptographic Multiparty Protocols (5-day minicourse in 2001) |accessdate=2010-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607223418/http://www.win.tue.nl/wsk/eidma/courses/minicourses/damgaord/MC-00-23.html |archivedate=2011-06-07 |df= }} He earned his PhD degree in May, 1988, with the thesis ''Ubetinget beskyttelse i kryptografiske protokoller'' (Unconditional protection in cryptographic protocols) and has been employed at Aarhus University ever since. Damgård was made full professor in 2005.{{cite web|url=http://interntnyt.katrinebjerg.net/05/26/ivan.html|title=180705 - Ivan Damgård ny professor|work=(in Danish)|accessdate=2018-03-02}} He is known among other things for the [[Merkle–Damgård construction]] used in most modern [[cryptographic hash function]]s such as [[SHA-1]] and [[MD5]]. He discovered the structure independently of [[Ralph Merkle]] and published it in 1989.I. Damgård. ''A Design Principle for Hash Functions''. In Advances in Cryptology - CRYPTO '89 Proceedings, Lecture Notes in Computer Science Vol. 435, G. Brassard, ed, Springer-Verlag, 1989, pp. 416-427. Ivan Damgård is also one of the founders of the [[Cryptomathic]] company. In 2010, he was selected as IACR Fellow.{{cite web|url=https://www.iacr.org/fellows/2010/ | title=2010 IACR Fellows | accessdate=2010-06-05}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.daimi.au.dk/~ivan/ Home page of Ivan Damgård] *{{MathGenealogy|id=66030}} * [http://www.informatik.uni-trier.de/~ley/db/indices/a-tree/d/Damg=aring=rd:Ivan.html A list of publications of Ivan Damgård] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Damgard, Ivan}} [[Category:Danish scientists]] [[Category:Danish computer scientists]] [[Category:Modern cryptographers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:International Association for Cryptologic Research fellows]] [[Category:Aarhus University faculty]]

'''Jared Genser''' is an international human rights lawyer who serves as managing director of the law firm Perseus Strategies, LLC.<ref name="perseus-strategies">{{cite web|url=https://www.perseus-strategies.com/team/|title=Team|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=perseus-strategies.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He is founder of [[Freedom Now]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.umich.edu/newsandinfo/features/Pages/jaredgenser_humanrightsaward080613.aspx|title=MLaw Grad, Freedom Now Founder Receives ABA's International Human Rights Award|last=Atherton|first=Lori|date=6 August 2013|website=Michigan Law|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 August 2018}}</ref> Genser is a Senior Fellow at the [[Raoul Wallenberg Centre for Human Rights]], was an Associate of the [[Carr Center for Human Rights Policy]] at [[Harvard University]] from 2014-2016, a Visiting Fellow with the [[National Endowment for Democracy]] from 2006-2007,<ref>National Endowment for Democracy (1 November 2006).[http://www.ned.org/for-reporters/ned-welcomes-fall-2006-reagan-fascell-democracy-fellows "NED Welcomes Fall 2006 Reagan-Fascell Democracy Fellows"]. Retrieved 21 October 2013.</ref> and earlier in his career was named by the ''National Law Journal'' as one of [http://www.law.com/jsp/nlj/PubArticleNLJ.jsp?id=1202432176120&slreturn=20130921115713 "40 Under 40: Washington's Rising Stars]." <ref>National Law Journal (13 July 2009). "40 Under 40". The National Law Journal. Retrieved 17 October 2013.</ref>
Genser previously served as international counsel to a number of prominent human rights activists and defenders, including [[Václav Havel]], [[Aung San Suu Kyi]], [[Desmond Tutu]], and [[Elie Wiesel]], and [[Liu Xiaobo]] and his wife Liu Xia.<ref name="perseus-strategies" /> Among his current clients are imprisoned Venezuelan politician [[Leopoldo López]], former Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister [[Anwar Ibrahim]], and former Maldives President [[Mohamed Nasheed]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.perseus-strategies.com/clients/|title=Clients|last=|first=|date=|website=Perseus Strategies|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In 2013, he received the [[American Bar Association]]'s International Human Rights Award.<ref>American Bar Association (6 August 2013). [http://www.americanbar.org/news/abanews/aba-news-archives/2013/08/lawyer_jared_genser.html “Lawyer Jared Genser to receive International Human Rights Award from American Bar Association”]. ABA News. Retrieved 17 October 2013.</ref>
== Early life and education ==
Genser was born in [[New Haven, Connecticut]], and grew up in suburban Maryland. Genser received a B.S. from [[Cornell University]] in 1995.<ref name=":0" /> He subsequently earned a Master in Public Policy degree from the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]] at Harvard University, where he was an Alumni Public Service Fellow and a J.D. ''cum laude'' from the [[University of Michigan Law School]].<ref name="perseus-strategies" /> He was also a Raoul Wallenberg Scholar at [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]].<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://news.cornell.edu/stories/2009/12/alumnus-fights-freedom-political-prisoners|title=Jared Genser '95 Fights for Freedom of Political Prisoners|last=Hall|first=Sheri|date=8 December 2009|website=Cornell Chronicle|publisher=Cornell University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.cornell.edu/stories/1996/04/karin-klapper-96-named-raoul-wallenberg-scholar|title=Karin Klapper '96 is Name Raoul Wallenberg Scholar|last=Goetz|first=Jill|date=15 April 1996|website=Cornell Chronicle|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Career ==
Genser began his career as a management consultant with [[McKinsey & Company]].<ref name="perseus-strategies" /> He later joined [[DLA Piper]], where he was elected a partner.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/dla-piper-alum-launches-practice-focused-on-humanitarian-issues/2011/06/29/AGX7QTwH_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.1573a5b8665b|title=DLA Piper Alum Launches Practice Focused on Humanitarian Issues|last=Ho|first=Catherine|date=3 July 2011|work=The Washington Post|access-date=30 August 2018}}</ref> In 2011, he left DLA Piper to found Perseus Strategies, a human-rights law firm.<ref name="abajournal">McDonough, Molly (5 July 2011). [http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/partner_leaves_dla_to_launch_firm_focused_on_international_human_rights_iss/ “Partner Leaves DLA to Launch Firm Focused on International Human Rights Issues”]. ABA Journal. Retrieved 14 October 2013.</ref> Genser has served as an adjunct professor of law at [[Georgetown University Law Center]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.georgetown.edu/faculty/jared-genser/|title=Profile Jared Genser — Georgetown Law|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> [[University of Michigan Law School]], and [[University of Pennsylvania Law School]].<ref name="perseus-strategies" /> In June 2014 it was announced he would partner with the PR firm [[Levick (public relations firm)|Levick]] in regard to "the international and local media narrative" surrounding the Nigerian government's efforts on the [[Chibok schoolgirls kidnapping]].<ref>{{Cite web | last = Wilson | first = Megan R | title = Nigeria hires PR for Boko Haram fallout | work = TheHill | accessdate = 2014-06-30 | date = 2014-06-26 | url = http://thehill.com/business-a-lobbying/210635-nigeria-hires-pr-for-boko-haram-fallout }}</ref>
== Books and publications == Genser is the author of ''The UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention: Commentary and Guide to Practice''.<ref>Genser, Jared (Forthcoming 2019). ''The UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention: Commentary and Guide to Practice.'' Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press.</ref> He was also a co-editor with Canadian Member of Parliament [[Irwin Cotler]] for ''The Responsibility to Protect: The Promise of Stopping Mass Atrocities in Our Time''<ref>Genser, Jared; Cotler, Irwin (2012). ''The Responsibility to Protect: The Promise of Stopping Mass Atrocities in Our Time.'' Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|978-0199797769}}.</ref> and with former Minister of Foreign Affairs of Costa Rica [[Bruno Stagno Ugarte]] for ''The UN Security Council in the Age of Human Rights''.<ref>Genser, Jared; Ugarte, Bruno Stagno (2013). ''The United Nations Security Council in the Age of Human Rights.'' Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|978-1107040076}}.</ref>
Genser has published more than 180 op-eds on human-rights topics in major newspapers around the world including ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'', ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', ''[[The Chosun Ilbo]]'' (Seoul), ''[[Far Eastern Economic Review]]'', ''[[The Huffington Post]]'',<ref>Examples: * Irwin Cotler; Jared Genser (30 August 2013). [http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/irwin-cotler/syria-crisis_b_3845195.html “Our Response to Syria Must Be Effective, But Also Legal”]. Huffington Post. Retrieved 15 October 2013. * Jared Genser (7 December 2012). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jared-genser/liu-xiaobo_b_2259503.html “A Growing Movement to Support Liu Xiaobo”]. Huffington Post. Retrieved 15 October 2013. * Jared Genser (8 October 2012). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jared-genser/free-liu-xiaobo_b_1949469.html “Free Liu Xiaobo”]. Huffington Post. Retrieved 15 October 2013.</ref> ''[[The Independent]]'' (UK), ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'',<ref>Irwin Cotler; Jared Genser (28 February 2011). [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/01/opinion/01iht-edcotler01.html?_r=0 “Libya and the Responsibility to Protect”]. International Herald Tribune. Retrieved 15 October 2013.</ref> ''[[The Jakarta Post]]'', ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'',<ref>Desmond M. Tutu; Jared Genser (3 June 2013). [http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jun/03/opinion/la-oe-tutu-china-human-rights-20130604 “Stand up for Liu Xiaobo”]. Los Angeles Times. Retrieved 15 October 2013.</ref> ''[[South China Morning Post]]'',<ref>Jerome A. Cohen; Jared Genser (15 August 2013). [http://www.scmp.com/article/990949/harmful-effects “Harmful Effects: The Torture and Detention of Gao Zhisheng”]. South China Morning Post. Retrieved 15 October 2013.</ref> ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'',<ref>Jared Genser (25 June 2013). [http://www.smh.com.au/comment/more-clout-needed-to-end-north-koreas-oppression-20130625-2oujy.html “More Clout Needed to End North Korea’s Repression”]. Sydney Morning Herald. Retrieved 15 October 2013.</ref> ''[[The Nation (Thailand)|The Nation]]'' (Thailand), ''[[The Star (South Africa)|The Star]]'' (South Africa), ''[[The Times]]'' (UK), ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'',<ref>Examples: * Jared Genser; Julia Kuperminc (16 December 2015). [https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-human-rights-crisis-wracks-paradise-1450288162 "A Human-Rights Crisis Wracks Paradise."] Wall Street Journal. Retrieved 22 January 2016. * Bruce Klinger; Jared Genser (6 October 2013). [https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304171804579119173832719340 “How North Korea Gets Away With It”]. Wall Street Journal (Asia). Retrieved 15 October 2013. * Jared Genser (25 April 2013). [https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324474004578444461150538322 “In China, Repression Is a Family Affair”]. Wall Street Journal (Asia). Retrieved 15 October 2013. * Jared Genser; Kristen Abrams (22 March 2013). [https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887323419104578374470904536276 “For North Koreans in the Gulag, a Glimmer of Hope at the U.N.”]. Wall Street Journal. Retrieved 15 October 2013. * Jared Genser; Kristen Abrams (2 April 2013). [https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304023504577319463308130868 “Investigate North Korea’s Gulag”]. Wall Street Journal (Asia). Retrieved 15 October 2013. * Jared Genser (3 June 2010). [https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052748704025304575283893312534792 “Take Kim to Court”]. Wall Street Journal (Asia). Retrieved 15 October 2013.</ref> ''[[The New York Times]],'' and ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref>Examples:
Jared Genser (24 April 2015). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/preventing-atrocities-now--and-in-the-future/2015/04/24/f20b027e-e920-11e4-aae1-d642717d8afa_story.html "Preventing Atrocities Now - And in the Future."] Washington Post. Retrieved 22 January 2016.
Jared Genser (21 January 2013). [https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-01-20/opinions/36473923_1_human-rights-gulag-navanethem-pillay “Ignoring North Korea’s Gulags: A UN Human Rights Council Inquiry is the First Step”]. The Washington Post. Retrieved 15 October 2013. </ref>
== Other activities and awards ==
Genser is a life member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] and a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Arts]]. He was elected in 2008 as a Fellow to the British American Project. In 2009 he was elected as a Delegate to the Asia Society’s Asia 21 Young Leaders Summit and also as a U.S.-Japan Young Leadership Fellow.<ref name="perseus-strategies" /> Genser was a Young Global Leader of the [[World Economic Forum]] from 2008-2013 and a Member of the World Economic Forum's Global Agenda Council for Human Rights (2010-2011). In 2011, he was selected among the ''Young Leaders'' of the [[French-American Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://frenchamerican.org/young-leader/jared-genser/|title=Jared Genser - Young Leaders|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[French-American Foundation]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2015-10-26}}</ref> He is a recipient of the Charles Bronfman Prize and [[Liberty in North Korea]]'s Freedom Fighter Award.<ref name="perseus-strategies" /> In addition to being qualified to practice law in Maryland and the District of Columbia, he is also a Solicitor of England & Wales.<ref name="perseus-strategies" />

'''Kaljo Ellik''' (9 May 1948, [[Siiksaare]] – 27 March 2017)<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.postimees.ee/4060867/suri-20-augusti-klubi-liige-kaljo-ellik|title=Suri 20. Augusti Klubi liige Kaljo Ellik|access-date=26 May 2018|date=28 March 2017|publisher=postimees.ee|last=Kangro|first=Karin|language=Estonian}}</ref> was an Estonian politician who was a voter for the [[Estonian restoration of Independence]].
Ellik graduated in 1963 from [[Kingisepp]] 1st Secondary School, in 1968 from [[Räpina]] Horticultural Engineering School, and in 1975 from the [[Estonian University of Life Sciences]]. In addition, he has studied social psychology at the Tartu Fine Arts Courses and the [[University of Tartu]].
He served as senior agronomist inspectorate in the Kingsepp District Seed Inspectorate from 1969 to 1979 and from 1978 to 1990 as vice chairman of the Executive Committee of the Council of People's Deputies of Kingissepp. In 1990, he was Deputy Mayor of [[Kuressaare]].
From [[Estonian Supreme Soviet election, 1990|1990]] to 1992, he was a member of the Supreme Council of the Republic of Estonia, and on 20 August 1991 he voted in favor of the restoration of Estonia's independence. He was also an ambassador to the [[Congress of Estonia]]. On 18 September 1991, he became a member of the [[Estonian Centre Party]].
==Awards== *[[Order of the National Coat of Arms|5th Class of the Estonian Order of the National Coat of Arms]] (received 23 February 2002)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.president.ee/en/estonia/decorations/bearer/1066/kaljo-ellik|title=Bearer of decorations: Kaljo Ellik (V)|access-date=26 May 2018|date=|publisher=Estonian State Decorations}}</ref> *[[Order of the National Coat of Arms|3rd Class of the Estonian Order of the National Coat of Arms]] (received 23 February 2006)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.president.ee/en/estonia/decorations/bearer/1147/kaljo-ellik|title=Bearer of decorations: Kaljo Ellik (III)|access-date=26 May 2018|date=|publisher=Estonian State Decorations}}</ref> * 2008: Order of the City of Kuressaare

{{Buddhism}} [[File:Siddharta parting from Kanthaka and Chandaka BM OA1880.65.jpg|thumb|Siddhartha parting from Kanthaka, [[Gandhara]], [[British Museum]]]] [[File:KITLV 88034 - Unknown - Relief of Chanda and Kanthaka in British India - 1897.tif|thumb|Relief of Chanda and Kanthaka in British India, 1897]]
'''Kanthaka''' (in [[Pali language|Pali]] and [[Sanskrit language|Sanskrit]]) (6th century BC, in [[Kapilavastu (ancient city)|Kapilvastu]] and [[Tilaurakot]], [[Nepal]]) was a favourite white [[horse]] of length eighteen cubits that was a royal servant of Prince Siddhartha, who later became [[Gautama Buddha]]. Siddhartha used Kanthaka in all major events described in [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] texts prior to his renunciation of the world. Following the departure of Siddhartha, Kanthaka died of a broken heart.<ref name="encyc">{{cite book|title=Encyclopaedia of Buddhism| last = Malasekera| first = G. P. |year =1996| publisher = [[Government of Sri Lanka]]}}</ref>
In the court of King [[Suddhodarna]], Kanthaka was the most skillful and able horse, and the favourite of Crown Prince [[Gautama Buddha|Siddhartha]], whenever Siddhartha needed to go outside the palace. Siddhartha had been lavished and pampered in a series of purpose-built palaces by Suddhodarna in order to shield him from thoughts of pain and suffering. This was done due to a prophecy by the ascetic [[Asita]], who predicted that Siddhartha would renounce the throne to become a spiritual leader were he to contemplate human suffering. Kanthaka is first described in relation to the events leading up to the marriage of Siddhartha to [[Yasodhara]], another Sakyan princess. By the customs of the [[kshatriya]] Sakyan clan, a prince must prove his worthiness in warrior related skills such as horse-riding, mounted archery and swordplay by defeating other royals in such contests. Mounted on Kanthaka, Siddhartha defeated his cousin [[Devadatta]] in archery, another cousin [[Anuruddha]] in a horse-riding competition and then half-brother [[Nanda]] in swordplay.
After Siddhartha's marriage, Kanthaka was the horse pulling the chariot when [[Channa (Buddhist)|Channa]], the head royal servant accompanied Siddhartha around [[Kapilavastu (ancient city)|Kapilavastu]] to see the [[Four sights]] whilst meeting his subjects, which prompted his decision to renounce the world. During these expeditions aboard Kanthaka, Channa explained to [[Gautama Buddha|Siddhartha]] the sights of an elderly man, a sick person, a dead person whose funeral was being conducted and finally, an [[ascetic]] who had renounced worldly life for a spiritual one, as Siddhartha who had been secluded from such sights within the palace was taken aback.
Later, Kanthaka was the horse used by Siddhartha to escape from the palace to become an ascetic, whilst the remainder of the palace guards were asleep. After initially protesting and refusing to accept that Siddhartha would leave him, Channa saddled Kanthaka,<ref>http://www.rootinstitute.com/buddhism_shakyamuni_sorrow.html</ref> guiding him out of the town aboard the horse to a forest by the edge of the [[Anoma River]].<ref>http://www.watlaori.org/who%20is%20buddha.pdf{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> According to the texts, Kanthaka was able to jump across the river. Riding Kanthaka, Channa returned Siddhartha's accoutrements, weapons and hair to Suddhodarnha upon his return to the palace, after Siddhartha compelled him to return after Channa had refused to leave him.<ref name="encyc"/>
According to Buddhist texts, Kanthaka was reborn as a [[brahmin]] and went on to attend [[dharma]] talks by [[Gautama Buddha]] and achieve enlightenment. The death is variously described as occurring either at the banks of the Anoma or upon returning to Kapilavastu.<ref name="encyc"/>
The description of Kanthaka is also widely observed in Buddhist art, such as carvings on stupas. The depiction of Siddhartha leaving [[Kapilavastu (ancient city)|Kapilavastu]] aboard Kanthaka found at the main [[stupa]] in [[Amaravathi village, Guntur district|Amaravathi]] is the oldest depiction currently existing. Such depictions are also displayed in museums in [[London]] and [[Calcutta]].

page.title: List of people from Central Italy

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} This is a '''list of notable [[Central Italy|central Italians]]'''. [[File:Italia centrale.svg|200px|thumb|right|Central Italy comprises four regions: [[Tuscany]], Umbria, [[Marche]], and [[Lazio]], which hosts Rome, the Capital city.]] ==Architects== *[[Francesco Talenti]] (c. 1300 – aft. 1369), was an architect. He worked at [[Orvieto Cathedral]] in the 1320s, and succeeded Pisano at [[Florence Cathedral]] in c. 1343. *[[Filippo Brunelleschi]] (1377–1446), was an architect and polymathic [[genius]], who, among other achievements, was the discoverer of [[perspective (graphical)|linear perspective]]. *[[Michelozzo]] (1396–1472), was an architect and sculptor, notable in the development of Florentine [[Renaissance architecture]]. *[[Bernardo Rossellino]] (1409–1464), was an architect as well as a sculptor and carried out the building of the [[Palazzo Rucellai]]. *[[Giuliano da Sangallo]] (c. 1445 – 1516), an architect, engineer, and sculptor, was active in Florence, Rome, Naples and Milan. *[[Baccio Pontelli]] (c. 1450 – 1492), was an architect and sculptor. Pupil of Francesco di Giorgio. *[[Antonio da Sangallo the Elder]] (c. 1453 – 1534), Renaissance architect among whose works was [[San Biagio, Montepulciano|San Biagio]] near [[Montepulciano]]. *[[Baccio D'Agnolo]] (1462–1543), was a "wood-carver, sculptor, and architect who exerted an important influence on the Renaissance architecture of Florence."[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/47818/Baccio-dAgnolo Baccio d'Agnolo.] Encyclopædia Britannica Online, 2014. Web. 11 March 2014. *[[Antonio da Sangallo the Younger]] (1484–1546), was "one of the most distinguished architects... in the second quarter of 16th century."Curl, James Stevens. [http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100440633 Antonio da Sangallo, the Younger.] In A Dictionary of Architecture and Landscape Architecture, 2006. Oxford Index – Oxford University Press. Web. 16 March 2014. *[[Jacopo Sansovino]] (1486–1570), was an architect and sculptor, most famous for his works in Venice's [[Piazza San Marco]], particularly his [[Biblioteca Marciana]]. *[[Giulio Romano]] (c. 1499 – 1546), architect, painter and decorator, whose real name was Giulio Pippi. "He was one of the major figures of the late [[Renaissance]]."Curl, James Stevens. [https://books.google.com/books?id=jIWr0IO9dYIC&pg=PA317&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false ''A Dictionary of Architecture and Landscape Architecture.''] Oxford University Press, 2006. p. 317. Web. 3 April 2014. *[[Galeazzo Alessi]] (1512–1572), was an important High Renaissance architect, best known for his work in [[Genoa]] and [[Milan]]. *[[Bernardo Buontalenti]] (c. 1531 – 1608), architect, engineer, designer, painter, and inventor. He was one of the great Renaissance [[polymath]]s. *[[Nicola Sabbatini]] (1574–1654), was an architect and engineer "who pioneered in theatrical perspective techniques."[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/514984/Nicola-Sabbatini Nicola Sabbatini.] Encyclopædia Britannica Online, 2014. Web. 20 March 2014. *[[Gherardo Silvani]] (1579–1675), was a Baroque architect of distinction. His main work is the church of [[San Gaetano, Florence|San Gaetano]] in [[Florence]]. *[[Carlo Rainaldi]] (1611–1691), was one of the most important architects in Rome during the second half of the 17th century.Mena, Manuela. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=H8Q7U5LZFIrmywPxqIGwCg&hl=it&id=FS5LAQAAIAAJ&dq= ''Italian drawings of the 17th and 18th centuries from the Biblioteca Nacional of Madrid.''] Spanish Institute, 1989. p. 63. Web. 2 April 2014.
"Carlo Rainaldi, one of the most important architects in Rome during the second half of the century, was the son of [[Girolamo Rainaldi]], a Roman architect who was trained in the mannerist style." *[[Domenico Martinelli]] (1650–1718), was an architect and painter. Among his best works is the palace of Prince Lichtenstein at Vienna. *[[Alessandro Specchi]] (1668–1729), "was an able civic designer who, among other works, began the delightful Scala di Spagna, Rome ([[Spanish Steps]])."Fletcher, Banister ; Palmes, James C. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=5pQ9U9zEFamBywOAw4GgBw&hl=it&id=nQcGpsLgW6MC&dq= ''Sir Banister Fletcher's A History of Architecture.''] Athlone Press, 1975. p. 851. Web. 3 April 2014. *[[Alessandro Galilei]] (1691–1737), was one of a number of gifted architects whose work moved away from [[Baroque]] towards [[Neoclassicism]]. *[[Nicola Salvi]] (1697–1751), was an architect. He is now remembered for his work at the ''[[Trevi Fountain]]'', the last great baroque monument in Rome. *[[Ferdinando Fuga]] (1699–1782), was an architect. He is best known for his rebuilding of [[Santa Maria Maggiore]] in Rome. *[[Giuseppe Piermarini]] (1734–1808), was "the leading architect in [[Lombardy]] during the last quarter of the 18th century."Anderson, Stanford ; Wilson, Colin St. John. [https://books.google.com/books?id=jc5HAQAAIAAJ&q= ''The Oxford companion to architecture.''] Oxford University Press, 2009. p. 717. Web. 18 March 2014. *[[Louis Visconti]] (1791–1853), was an architect active in France. His most significant project was the design for [[:File:Paris - Dôme des Invalides - Tombeau de Napoléon - 002.jpg|Bonaparte's Tomb]]. *[[Enrico Marconi]] (January 1792 – 1863), was an architect. From 1822 to his death, he was active in [[Poland]]. *[[Antonio Corazzi]] (December 1792 – 1877), was one of the principal authors of the architecture of [[Warsaw]] in the first half of the 19th century. *[[Marcello Piacentini]] (1881–1960), was an architect. Son of [[Pio Piacentini]], and principal architect in Rome during the [[Italian Fascism|Fascist regime]]. *[[Italo Gismondi]] (1887–1974), was an architect and archaeologist. He also created the [[:File:RomemodelEUR3.jpg|plastic model of ancient Rome]] displayed in the [[Museum of Roman Civilization]]. *[[Pietro Belluschi]] (1899–1994), was an architect, civil engineer, and designer. He won the 1972 [[AIA Gold Medal]]. *[[Luigi Moretti]] (1907–1973), was an architect. His most notable work is the [[Watergate complex]] in Washington, D.C. *[[Pietro Porcinai]] (1910–1986), was an artist, furniture designer, architect, and landscape architect, who began his career as a garden designer in 1937. *[[Massimiliano Fuksas]] (born 1944), is an architect. Among his works may be cited the ''[[:File:Vienna Twin Tower.jpg|Twin Tower]]'', [[Vienna]] (1999–01), and the ''[[:File:FieraMilano2.jpg|FieraMilano]]'' complex, [[Milan]] (2002–05). ==Chess players== *[[Serafino Dubois]] (1817–1899), was the leading Italian chess player for most of the mid 1800s.Sunnucks, Anne. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=YrA2U-bfA6qI4ASknoCQAg&hl=it&id=HJkYAAAAIAAJ&dq= ''The encyclopaedia of chess.''] Hale, 1976. p. 114. Web. 29 March 2014.
"During the middle of the last century Dubois was the strongest player in Italy." *[[Antonio Sacconi]] (1895–1968), was a chess player. [[International Master]] (1951) and [[Italian Chess Championship|Italian Champion]] in 1935 and joint Champion in 1937. ==Cinematography== *[[Augusto Genina]] (1892–1957), was a director and writer, known for ''[[Bengasi (film)|Bengasi]]'', ''[[The Siege of the Alcazar]]'', and ''[[Heaven over the Marshes]]''. *[[Mario Camerini]] (1895–1981), was a director and writer, known for ''[[Ulysses (1955 film)|Ulysses]]'', ''[[Una romantica avventura]]'', and ''[[War and Peace (1956 film)|War and Peace]]''. *[[Alessandro Blasetti]] (1900–1987), was a director and writer, known for ''[[The Iron Crown]]'', ''[[Prima comunione]]'', and ''[[Me, Me, Me... and the Others]]''. *[[Aldo Fabrizi]] (1905–1990), was an actor and director. He is best remembered for his performance in the Rossellini film, ''[[Rome, Open City]]''. *[[Roberto Rossellini]] (1906–1977), was the first neorealist film director to rise to international acclaim with the release of ''Rome, Open City''. *[[Anna Magnani]] (1908–1973), was an actress who won an Oscar for her performance in the screen adaptation of Tennessee Williams' ''[[The Rose Tattoo (film)|The Rose Tattoo]]''. *[[Gillo Pontecorvo]] (1919–2006), was a film director. He is best remembered for ''[[The Battle of Algiers]]'', regarded by many critics as a masterpiece. *[[Alberto Sordi]] (1920–2003), was an actor who depicted Italy's virtues and vices in more than 160 movies and contributed to making Italian comedy famous worldwide. *[[Carlo Lizzani]] (April 1922 – 2013), was a director and writer, known for ''[[The Hunchback of Rome]]'', ''[[Bandits in Milan]]'', and ''[[Celluloide]]''. *[[Mauro Bolognini]] (June 1922 – 2001), was a prolific director admired, above all, for his elegant adaptations of literary works, made mostly in the 1960s and 1970s. *[[Giuseppe Rotunno]] (born 1923), cinematographer. He is known for his work on ''[[The Adventures of Baron Munchausen]]'', ''[[Wolf (1994 film)|Wolf]]'', and ''[[Amarcord]]''. *[[Gabriele Ferzetti]] (born 1925), is an actor, known for ''[[Once Upon a Time in the West]]'', ''[[L'Avventura]]'', and ''[[On Her Majesty's Secret Service (film)|On Her Majesty's Secret Service]]''. *[[Sergio Corbucci]] (1926–1990), was a director, known for ''[[The Great Silence]]'', ''[[Navajo Joe]]'', and ''[[Gli specialisti]]''. *[[Lucio Fulci]] (1927–1996), also known as The Godfather of Gore, was a film director, screenwriter, and actor. *[[Sergio Leone]] (3 January 1929 – 1989), was one of the most important directors of his generation. He is mostly associated with the [[Spaghetti Western]] genre. *[[Elio Petri]] (29 January 1929 – 1982), was a writer and director, known for ''[[Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion]]'', ''[[A Quiet Place in the Country]]'', and ''[[The Assassin (1961 film)|The Assassin]]''. *[[Silvana Mangano]] (April 1930 – 1989), was an actress. She is best known for her role in the film ''[[Bitter Rice]]''. *[[Antonio Margheriti]] (September 1930 – 2002), was a director and writer, known for ''[[Yor, the Hunter from the Future]]'', ''[[Cannibal Apocalypse]]'', and ''[[Horror Castle]]''. *[[Virna Lisi]] (born 1936), is an actress. In 1994, she won two awards: [[Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Cannes Film Festival award]] and [[César award]]. *[[Giuliano Gemma]] (1938–2013), was an actor. ''[[A Pistol for Ringo]]'', ''[[The Return of Ringo]]'', and ''[[Blood for a Silver Dollar]]'' are among his greatest successes. *[[Osvaldo Desideri]] (born 1939), is an art director. He won an Oscar for [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Best Art Direction]] and [[Set Decoration]] (with [[Bruno Cesari|Cesari]] and [[Ferdinando Scarfiotti|Scarfiotti]]) for ''[[The Last Emperor]]''. *[[Vittorio Storaro]] (born 1940), is an award-winning cinematographer who won Oscars for ''[[Apocalypse Now]]'', ''[[Reds (film)|Reds]]'', and ''[[The Last Emperor]]''. *[[Manlio Rocchetti]] (born 1943), is a makeup artist. He won an Oscar for [[Academy Award for Best Makeup and Hairstyling|Best Makeup]] (with [[Lynn Barber (make-up artist)|Lynn Barber]] and [[Kevin Haney]]) for ''[[Driving Miss Daisy]]''. *[[Isabella Rossellini]] (June 1952), actress and model. She is probably best known for her role as Dorothy Vallens in the 1986 [[David Lynch]] film ''[[Blue Velvet (film)|Blue Velvet]]''. *[[Roberto Benigni]] (October 1952), is an actor, director and producer best known for his 1997 Oscar-winning film ''[[Life Is Beautiful]]''. *[[Nanni Moretti]]{{#tag:ref|Born in [[Bruneck]] from [[Rome|Roman]] parents.|group="nb"}} (born 1953), is a director, producer, screenwriter, and actor. ''[[Ecce Bombo]]'' is generally considered his masterpiece. *[[Margherita Buy]] (born 1962), is an actress, known for ''[[The Ignorant Fairies]]'', ''[[The Caiman]]'', and ''[[Days and Clouds]]''. *[[Gabriele Muccino]] (born 1967), is a director and writer, known for ''[[The Pursuit of Happyness]]'', ''[[Seven Pounds]]'', and ''[[The Last Kiss (2001 film)|The Last Kiss]]''. *[[Matteo Garrone]] (born 1968), is a writer and director, known for ''[[Gomorrah (film)|Gomorrah]]'', ''[[Reality (2012 film)|Reality]]'', and ''[[L'imbalsamatore]]''. *[[Asia Argento]] (born 1975), is a director, writer and actress. She is the daughter of the famous horror director [[Dario Argento]]. ==Economists== *[[Pellegrino Rossi]] (1787–1848), was a law expert, economist, diplomat, active in Swiss, French, and Italian politics. *[[Franco Modigliani]] (1918–2003), was an economist. He won the 1985 [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] for his pioneering work in economic theory. *[[Mario Draghi]] (born 1947), is a banker and economist. In 2013 ''[[Forbes]]'' nominated Draghi [[Forbes Magazine's List of The World's Most Powerful People|9th most powerful person in the world]]. ==Engineers== *[[Felice Matteucci]] (1808–1887), was a hydraulic engineer, co-inventor with [[Eugenio Barsanti]], of the [[internal combustion engine]].Day, Lance ; McNeil, Ian. [https://books.google.com/books?id=FmoTeX3aGl4C&pg=PA816&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Biographical Dictionary of the History of Technology.''] Routledge, 2002. p. 816. Web. 19 March 2014. *[[Filippo Zappata]] (1894–1994), was an engineer and one of the most important designers of seaplanes.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=GJAYU9iqJcmGtAaD3YFw&hl=it&id=CQYwAQAAIAAJ&dq= ''Casabella.''] Domus, 1998. p. 36. Web. 6 March 2014. *[[Riccardo Morandi]] (1902–1989), was a civil engineer. One of his most famous executed projects is the [[General Rafael Urdaneta Bridge|bridge]] on [[Lake Maracaibo]] in Venezuela. ==Engravers== *[[Maso Finiguerra]] (1426–1464), was a goldsmith, engraver, and draftsman, known for his work in [[niello]], and as "one of the first major Italian printmakers."[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/207338/Maso-Finiguerra Maso Finiguerra.] Encyclopædia Britannica Online, 2014. Web. 11 March 2014. *[[Stefano della Bella]] (1610–1664), was a printmaker noted for his engravings of military events, in the manner of [[Jacques Callot]]. *[[Francesco Bartolozzi]] (1727–1815), was an engraver in the service of [[George III of the United Kingdom]]. *[[Bartolomeo Pinelli]] (1771–1835), was a painter and engraver who illustrated the works of [[Virgil]], amongst others and published albums of numerous classical subjects. ==Explorers== *[[Amerigo Vespucci]] (1454–1512), was an explorer for whom the Americas were named. *[[Orazio Antinori]] (1811–1882), was a zoologist and African explorer, born at [[Perugia]]. ==Fashion designers== *[[Guccio Gucci]] (1881–1953), was a fashion designer and founder of [[Gucci|The House of Gucci]]. *[[Roberto Cavalli]] (born 1940), is a well-known fashion designer of modern luxury clothing. *[[Laura Biagiotti]] (born 1943), is a fashion designer affectionately known as the Queen of Cashmere.{{it icon}} [http://www.affaritaliani.it/mode-talenti/biagiotti020813.html I settant'anni di Laura Biagiotti, la "Regina del cashmere."] Moda – Affaritaliani, 2013. Web. 27 March 2014. ==Fashion models== *[[Monica Bellucci]] (born 1964), is a model and actress. *[[Mariacarla Boscono]] (born 1980), is a model. *[[Ilary Blasi]] (born 1981), is a showgirl and model. *[[Vanessa Hessler]] (born 1988), is a model and actress. ==Military figures== *[[Castruccio Castracani]] (1281–1328), was a famous ''condottiero'' created duke of [[Lucca]] in 1327. *[[Niccolò Piccinino]] (1386–1444), ''condottiero'', was a cavalryman who spent the most important years of his career in the service of Milan. *[[Federico da Montefeltro]] (1422–1482), learned Renaissance prince who was an outstanding military leader and a great patron of the arts. *[[Vitellozzo Vitelli]] (c. 1458 – 1502), was a famous military leader or ''condottiero'' from Città di Castello, [[Umbria]]. *[[Cesare Borgia]] (1475/76 – 1507), was a Cardinal, military leader, and Machiavellian politician. He was the son of [[Pope Alexander VI]]. *[[Francesco Ferruccio]] (1489–1530), was a military commander. He served in the ''Bande Nere'' in various parts of Italy, earning a reputation as a daring fighter. *[[Alexander Farnese, Duke of Parma]] (1545–1592), was a famous military commander who served [[Philip II of Spain|Philip II]] and became governor-general of the Netherlands. *[[Ottavio Piccolomini]] (1599–1656), was duke of Amalfi and one of the most powerful people in Spain as well as a key player in the Thirty Years' War. *[[Pier Ruggero Piccio]] (1880–1965), a skilled war pilot, distinguished himself in [[World War I]] as a daring fighter pilot. He had a total of 24 victories. *[[Enrico Toti]] (1882–1916), was a cyclist, patriot and one of the greatest of Italy's war heroes. *[[Franco Lucchini]] (1917–1943), was a [[World War II]] fighter pilot with 26 individual victories and 52 shared. ==Missionaries== *[[Riccoldo da Monte di Croce]] (c. 1243 – 1320), was a Dominican missionary to the court of the Mongol [[Il-Khan]] ruler [[Arghun]]. *[[Matteo Ricci]] (1552–1610), was a Jesuit missionary and [[polymath]] who opened China to Roman Catholic evangelization. *[[Anthony Baldinucci]] (1665–1717), was a Jesuit missionary, popularized the image as he preached and created missions throughout Italy. *[[Teodorico Pedrini]] (1671–1746), was a priest, missionary, musician and composer in China. *[[Ippolito Desideri]] (1684–1733), was a Jesuit missionary, who visited [[Tibet]] in the early 18th century. ==Musicians== *[[Guido of Arezzo]] (c. 990 – 1050), was a "medieval music theorist whose principles served as a foundation for modern Western [[musical notation]]."[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/248582/Guido-dArezzo Guido d'Arezzo.] Encyclopædia Britannica Online, 2014. Web. 6 March 2014. *[[Antonio Squarcialupi]] (1416–1480), was an organist and composer. He was "the most famous Italian organist of his time."Stolba, K. Marie. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=MrYmU-rrLYjiywOFtoCwCw&hl=it&id=W8UZAQAAIAAJ&dq= ''The development of western music: a history.''] McGraw Hill, 1998. p. 118. Web. 17 March 2014. *[[Giovanni Animuccia]] (c. 1520 – 1571), was a composer. "Predecessor of Palestrina as maestro of the Vatican and regarded as extraordinarily fertile innovator."Kennedy, Michael ; Kennedy, Joyce. [https://books.google.com/books?id=XX2sAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA25&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Oxford Dictionary of Music.''] Oxford University Press, 2013. p. 25. Web. 9 March 2014. *[[Gioseffo Guami]] (1542–1611), was an organist and composer of motets, madrigals and canzonas representative of the [[Venetian School (music)|Venetian school]]. *[[Emilio de' Cavalieri]] (c. 1550 – 1602), was a composer and [[polymath]]. He lived mainly at the Florentine court of the [[Medici]], where he was Inspector General of Arts. *[[Giulio Caccini]] (1551–1618), a tenor, composer, and teacher was the most important member of the [[Florentine Camerata|Camerata]]. *[[Jacopo Peri]] (1561–1633), was a composer and singer. He is "often known as the 'inventor' of opera."Holden, Amanda. [https://books.google.com/books?id=h8UdHhxWH-sC&q= ''The new Penguin opera guide.''] Penguin, 2001. p. 665. Web. 1 April 2014. *[[Ottavio Rinuccini]] (1562–1621), was the first opera librettist, having produced the texts for Peri's ''[[Dafne]]'' and ''[[Euridice (Peri)|Euridice]]'', as well as Monteverdi's ''[[L'Arianna]]''. *[[Giovanni Francesco Anerio]] (c. 1567 – 1630), was an important composer and organist, brother of [[Felice Anerio]]. *[[Marco da Gagliano]] (1582–1643), was a celebrated composer. Gagliano's ''[[Dafne (Gagliano)|Dafne]]'', to a text by [[Ottavio Rinuccini|Rinuccini]], is a milestone in the early history of opera. *[[Gregorio Allegri]] (c. 1582 – 1652), was ''maestro di capella'' for [[Pope Urban VIII]]. He was seen as a successor to Palestrina. *[[Pietro Della Valle]] (1586–1652), composer, librettist, and theorist. Della Valle was also "a soldier, world traveler, and a passionate and articulate orientalist."Kipnis, Igor. [https://books.google.com/books?id=LG3DUo0pBckC&pg=PA147&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Harpsichord and Clavichord: An Encyclopedia.''] Routledge, 2004. p. 147. Web. 29 March 2014. *[[Stefano Landi]] (February 1587 – 1639), was an early Baroque composer whose large output includes operas, madrigals, arias, masses, and other sacred compositions. *[[Francesca Caccini]] (September 1587 – after 1641), known as La Cecchina, was a skilled composer, singer, and instrumentalist who served the [[Medici]] court in Florence. *[[Antonio Cesti]] (1623–1669), "composer who, with [[Francesco Cavalli]], was one of the leading Italian composers of the 17th century."[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/103869/Pietro-Antonio-Cesti Pietro Antonio Cesti.] Encyclopædia Britannica Online, 2014. Web. 6 March 2014. *[[Jean-Baptiste Lully]] (1632–1687), was a composer and founder of the French operatic tradition. His name originally was Giovanni Battista Lulli. *[[Alessandro Stradella]] (1639–1682), was one of the major composers of his era,[http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/public/ Alessandro Stradella.] Grove Music, Oxford University Press. Web. 3 April 2014.
"Stradella was one of the leading composers in Italy in his day and one of the most versatile. His music was widely admired, even as far afield as England. Most of it is clearly tonal, and counterpoint features prominently. His vocal output includes c 30 stage works, several oratorios and Latin church works and some 200 cantatas (most for solo voice)." writing some 30 stage works and 200 cantatas. *[[Benedetto Pamphili]] (1653–1730), was a cardinal, a patron of music in Rome and a librettist, especially important during [[Handel]]'s first year there. *[[Giuseppe Ottavio Pitoni]] (1657–1743), composer and writer on music. He was "one of the best and most prolific composers of sacred music of his time."Arnold, Denis. Hendricks | caption = | birth_name = Lola Mae Haynes | birth_date = 1932 | birth_place = [[Birmingham, Alabama]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (DEATH date then BIRTH date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = [[Clerk|Clerk-typist]], [[Secretary]] | years_active = | employer = [[Social Security Administration]], [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] | organization = [[Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights]], [[Southern Conference Education Fund]], [[Southern Christian Leadership Conference]], [[Birmingham Civil Rights Institute]] | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Lola Mae Haynes Hendricks''' ([[née]] Haynes) (born December 1932) was corresponding secretary for [[Fred Shuttlesworth|Fred Shuttlesworth's]] [[Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights]] from 1956 to 1963. She assisted [[Wyatt Walker]] in planning the early portions of the [[Southern Christian Leadership Conference|Southern Christian Leadership Conference's]] involvement in the 1963 [[Birmingham Campaign]] during the [[Civil Rights Movement]].<ref name=White>White, Marjorie Longenecker (1998) ''A Walk to Freedom: The Reverend Fred Shuttlesworth and the Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights, 1956-1964''. Birmingham: Birmingham Historical Society. {{ISBN|0-943994-24-1}}</ref>
==Early life== On December 19th, 1932 Lola Mae Haynes, the first of two daughters, was born to Buford and Addie Hanes.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://newpilgrim.org/wp-content/uploads/obits/lolahendricks.pdf |title=Lola Hendricks Obituary|date=May 24, 2013|website=New Pilgrim Baptist Church|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819191651/http://newpilgrim.org/wp-content/uploads/obits/lolahendricks.pdf |archivedate=August 19, 2016 |accessdate=June 1, 2017}}</ref> Lola Mae Haynes was born in [[Birmingham, Alabama]] on 4th Avenue and 15th Street South on the south side of Birmingham.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://library.duke.edu/digitalcollections/media/pdf/behindtheveil/btvct02013.pdf|title=Interview with Lola Haynes Hendricks|last=Whorley|first=Tywanna|date=June 22, 1994|website=Duke University Libraries|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Her father was employed as a coal-truck driver from [[LaGrange, Georgia]] and her mother, from [[Chambers County, Alabama]], worked as a domestic cook. Lola Mae Haynes went to school in Birmingham at Cameron Elementary School, graduated, and then went to Ullman High School for two years. In 1949, Haynes attended Parker High School for two years and graduated in January of '51.<ref name=":0" /> After graduating from Parker High School, she began working as an elevator operator at Hillman Hospital, now called University Hospital.<ref name=":0" /> Lola Mae Haynes saved her money from the hospital for a year, until she was able to enroll herself in beauty school in 1952 where she attended the Ruth Porter's School of Beauty Culture.
In February 1953, Lola Mae Haynes married Joseph Hendricks. Lola then went on to study for two years at the Booker T. Washington Business College. After graduating from Booker T. Washington Business College, Lola began employment in the [[insurance industry]] at Alexander & Company.<ref name=":1" /> The company, owned by John J. Drew and his wife Deanie, had employed Lola Mae Haynes Hendricks as a [[Clerk|clerk-typist]] and an insurance writer.<ref name="Interview">Huntley, Horace (January 19, 1995) [http://www.teachersdomain.org/asset/iml04_doc_fulllhen/ Interview with Lola Hendricks]. Birmingham Civil Rights Institute</ref> In 1963, Haynes began working for the Federal Government under the [[Social Security Administration]], where she became one of the first African Americans to integrate amongst the whites into the workforce. Hendricks worked in files for about two years, and then was promoted to Clerk Typing and again, to Award Typing.<ref name="Interview" />
==Civil Rights Movement== The Hendrickses were members of the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]] (NAACP). When the group was outlawed by the State of [[Alabama]] in 1956 she became one of the early members of the [[Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights]], joining at a mass meeting at Nelson Smith's New Pilgrim Baptist Church where she was a member.<ref name=Interview /> The ACMHR, led by Shuttlesworth, organized local boycotts and demonstrations as well as coordinating legal challenges to Birmingham's [[Jim Crow laws|segregation laws]] in the 1950s and 1960s.<ref name=White /> Hendricks and her husband were the named parties in ACMHR-backed lawsuits to force integration of Birmingham city parks and to desegregate the [[Birmingham Public Library]]. She also served as the organization's correspondence secretary, working from Shuttleworth's office at [[Bethel Baptist Church (Birmingham, Alabama)|Bethel Baptist Church]] from 1956 until the culmination of the [[Birmingham Campaign]].<ref name=White /> In December 1962 she traveled to [[New England]] as a field director for the [[Southern Conference Education Fund]], raising awareness among Northerners about the realities of Southern [[Segregation in the United States|segregation]] and soliciting donations of Christmas toys for movement members [[boycott]]ing Birmingham's [[Department store|department stores]].<ref name=Interview />
In the Spring of 1963, Hendricks coordinated the practical office requirements and cultivated local contacts for the combined efforts of the ACMHR and the [[Southern Christian Leadership Conference]] (SCLC), which Shuttlesworth had co-founded and which was chaired by [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]. She worked directly with the SCLC's [[Wyatt Walker]] during the campaign, helping organize support and logistics for marches and department store boycotts.<ref name=White />
It was Hendricks who applied directly to Public Safety Commissioner [[Bull Connor|Eugene "Bull" Connor]] for a parade permit for the first day of marches and was told "You will not get a permit in Birmingham, Alabama to picket. I'll picket you over to the jail."<ref name=McWhorter>[[Diane McWhorter|McWhorter, Diane]] (2001) ''Carry Me Home: Birmingham, Alabama, The Climactic Battle of the Civil Rights Revolution.'' New York, New York: Simon & Schuster. {{ISBN|0-7432-2648-8}}</ref> At Walker's urging she did not actively demonstrate and risk jailing, protecting her behind-the-scenes importance to the movement. Hendricks' nine-year-old daughter, Audrey Faye Hendricks (1952–2009), however, was the only child in her class to participate in the May 2, 1963 "[[Children's Crusade (civil rights)|Children's Crusade]]" that brought national attention to Connor's brutal tactics against demonstrators. She spent five nights in jail as minders got word out to her parents that she was safe.<ref name=Snajderman>Sznajderman, Michael (Fall 2003) "A dangerous business: Children on the front line." ''Alabama Heritage''</ref> She was the youngest known child to be arrested for that protest.<ref name="romper1">{{cite web|url=https://www.romper.com/p/16-childrens-books-about-martin-luther-king-jr-because-you-love-to-inspire-your-little-ones-8691108 |title=16 Children's Books About Martin Luther King Jr., Because You Love To Inspire Your Little Ones |publisher=Romper.com |date= |accessdate=2018-08-01}}</ref> The children's book ''The Youngest Marcher: The Story of Audrey Faye Hendricks, A Young Civil Rights Activist'' (2017) by Cynthia Levinson, is about that.<ref>{{cite web|author=Deborah Stevenson, Editor |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/646048 |title=Project MUSE - The Youngest Marcher: The Story of Audrey Faye Hendricks, a Young Civil Rights Activist by Cynthia Levinson (review) |doi=10.1353/bcc.2017.0116 |publisher=Muse.jhu.edu |date= |accessdate=2018-08-01}}</ref> That book also contains a recipe for Lola Hendricks’s "Hot Rolls Baptized in Butter".<ref>{{cite web|author=Deborah Stevenson, Editor |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/646048 |title=Project MUSE - The Youngest Marcher: The Story of Audrey Faye Hendricks, a Young Civil Rights Activist by Cynthia Levinson (review) |doi=10.1353/bcc.2017.0116 |publisher=Muse.jhu.edu |date= |accessdate=2018-08-01}}</ref>
==Later life== Hendricks left her insurance company job in 1963 to join the newly integrated Birmingham office of the [[Social Security Administration]]. She was hired originally as a filer, but was promoted to unit clerk before moving to the [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] where she became a supervisor. She left in 1983 to care for her mother. In 1988 she rejoined the Social Security Administration where she worked until reaching retirement.<ref name=Interview /> She continued to volunteer at the [[Birmingham Civil Rights Institute]] and in the mid 1990s she assisted the Birmingham Historical Society in researching movement churches and landmarks for [[National Register of Historic Places]] status.<ref name=White />
She has two sisters (one deceased), two daughters, Audrey Faye Hendricks (1952–2009) and Jan Hendricks Fuller, and one grandson, Joel A. Fuller. Audrey Faye Hendricks (1952–2009), at the age of nine, was the only child in her class to participate in the May 2, 1963 "[[Children's Crusade (civil rights)|Children's Crusade]]" that brought national attention to [[Bull Connor|Eugene "Bull" Connor]]'s brutal tactics against demonstrators. She spent five nights in jail as minders got word out to her parents that she was safe.<ref name=Snajderman>Sznajderman, Michael (Fall 2003) "A dangerous business: Children on the front line." ''Alabama Heritage''</ref> She was the youngest known child to be arrested for that protest.<ref name="romper1"/> The children's book ''The Youngest Marcher: The Story of Audrey Faye Hendricks, A Young Civil Rights Activist'' (2017) by Cynthia Levinson, is about that.<ref>{{cite web|author=Deborah Stevenson, Editor |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/646048 |title=Project MUSE - The Youngest Marcher: The Story of Audrey Faye Hendricks, a Young Civil Rights Activist by Cynthia Levinson (review) |doi=10.1353/bcc.2017.0116 |publisher=Muse.jhu.edu |date= |accessdate=2018-08-01}}</ref> That book also contains a recipe for Lola Hendricks’s "Hot Rolls Baptized in Butter".<ref>{{cite web|author=Deborah Stevenson, Editor |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/646048 |title=Project MUSE - The Youngest Marcher: The Story of Audrey Faye Hendricks, a Young Civil Rights Activist by Cynthia Levinson (review) |doi=10.1353/bcc.2017.0116 |publisher=Muse.jhu.edu |date= |accessdate=2018-08-01}}</ref>

'''Luciana Gimenez Morad''' (born November 3, 1969) is a [[Brazil]]ian television host and former model.
She became famous after she became pregnant with [[Mick Jagger]]'s child while he was married to super model [[Jerry Hall]]. DNA tests confirmed Lucas Maurice Morad-Jagger was Jagger's son.
==Biography== Gimenez was born in [[São Paulo|São Paulo, Brazil]]. Her father João Morad, businessman and nightclub entrepreneur, threw a six-day party to celebrate her birth. Her half-brother, Marco Antônio Gimenez, and their mother, Vera Gimenez, are Brazilian actors. She is of Lebanese and Spanish heritage.
She speaks four languages fluently: her native [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] and [[Italian language|Italian]].
==Career== [[File:LucianaGimenezCannes8.jpg|thumb|Luciana Gimenez in 2013]] Luciana started her modeling career at age 13, and has worked in many cities around the world, such as Paris, Hamburg, [[Milan]] and New York.
Luciana went on to become a TV hostess on Brazil's RedeTV!, and her show is the primetime show ''Superpop''.
She has already been endorsed by brands such as: [[Chanel]], [[Osklen]], [[Marks & Spencer]], [[Azzedine Alaïa]].
After research done by [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], Luciana was invited to participate in the program ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'' on June 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Get the Lowdown on Today's Co-Host Luciana Gimenez |url=http://beta.abc.go.com/shows/the-view/blogs/celebrities/get-the-lowdown-on-luciana-gimenez |work=[[American Broadcasting Company]] |accessdate=11 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617131218/http://beta.abc.go.com/shows/the-view/blogs/celebrities/get-the-lowdown-on-luciana-gimenez |archivedate=June 17, 2013 |df= }}</ref> One of the main issues addressed by the program was the campaign against the prevention of communicable disease by prostitutes.
==Personal life== Her son with musician [[Mick Jagger]], Lucas Maurice Morad-Jagger was born on May 18, 1999.
She was married Marcelo de Carvalho, who owns RedeTV!, from August 19, 2006 to 2018. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://bestuff.com/stuff/luciana-gimenez-morad |title=Luciana Gimenez Morad (The Best Woman on TV) |publisher=Webcache.googleusercontent.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116142555/http://bestuff.com/stuff/luciana-gimenez-morad |archivedate=January 16, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Gimenez and Carvalho have one child Lorenzo Gabriel Morad-Fragali (born in New York City on February 24, 2011).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gente.ig.com.br/nasce+lorenzo+gabriel+segundo+filho+de+luciana+gimenez/n1238110433077.html |title=Nasce Lorenzo Gabriel, segundo filho de Luciana Gimenez |publisher=Gente – iG |date=February 24, 2011 |accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref>
